content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Spore may not be what I was expecting. It may not be as good as I thought it could be. But once I looked past the dissappointment, I realised that there is still a good game here.Let me get the things that upset me out of the way. The Creature stage seems to last too long with little variation. You either kill everyone around you, or charm them. And charming is a bit confusing, so it always boils down to me killing off races of animals and watching the progress bar rise ever so slightly each time.Space stage is practically pointless. I feel that there is no goal in it. Sometimes, there are parts of space you can't  get to because they are just a tiny bit too far away. Cell stage was funner than both of these, which is pretty sad. City Stage is too short. It only lasts an hour and a half, at the most. Which sucks, because it's my favorite stage. You get to command vehicles you created to destroy other cities and conquer them. But the biggest danger in City Stage is turrets, not enemy vehicles.That's about it for the things I dislike, so on the the praising for Spore's creativity.CREATING THINGS IS GREAT. They made spinoffs based only on the Spore Creators, and there is a reason for that. You can construct creatures ranging from spiders with dolphin heads to dragons with butterfly wings and a human nose. It's great. The Vehicle Creators are my absolute favorite part of the game. I have created Spaceships of every shape and size, and i am proud of them. You will never see the same ship twice, unless someone actually made a duplicate. I feel like the game would be cooler if more people played and interacted, creating new creatures, buildings (oh yeah, you can create buildings. not my favorite.), and vehicles. But that's just me. Maybe? People, join me, i'm lonely.Spore is not a bad game, as long as you are creative and can deal with a bit of boring gameplay early on. You can create endless creatures, vehicles, and building with endless variety. The Tribal and City stages are fun, but short. good thing you can repeat them any time. I give Spore a 6/10, and I do recommend this game.(this is my first long review)

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												The first thing everyone asks (or should ask) about a game is "what kind of game is it?".Spore((tm) is, well, Spore(tm).It doesn't fit into any one genre, apart from possibly sandbox.There's no other game like it.NOTE: Only mouse over spoilers if you feel you can handle mature content.Swear words can make your head explode if you're not careful.When starting my Spore(tm) game, I chose a planet and a difficulty.I chose "easy", because I'm a wimp and I'd never played the game before.Asteroids pelted the planet of my choice in a melodramatic armaggedon, making craters and levelling mountains, splashing into the oceans.The camera zoomed in...in...in...it was deep under the ocean...an asteroid cracked open...and a sperm fused with a corn dog (spermdog?) popped out of the asteroid.Oh wait.That's me.I swam around, chomping up algae and chunks of unnameable meat indiscriminately, until I came across a cell far too big to be legally called a cell (you imposter!).It attempted to swallow me in its ginormous mandibles (of which it had far too many), and I could only swim away, flagella wiggling at  top speed.Eventually I got away, and the game told me to "call a mate".I did, and my spermdog sent out a little screech, met another spermdog, and got ready for some lovin'.To all you perverts out there: don't get your hopes up, they just dance around and lay an egg.Sexy.I was allowed to make some tweaks to my cell's design.I gave it spikes, a third eye, and an electric butt.He then hatched from an egg cell thing.This went on for a few minutes, until suddenly my triklopticus (for that is what I named him) grew a brain and started wishing for legs.I then advanced to the Creature stage, which consisted of adding legs to an already absurd design, and watched a dozen little leggy spermdogs run up onto dry land.The Creature stage kept the "mating" mechanic, but I was now running around on dry land eating stuff and meeting other species.I had the option of making friends with them or eating them.After ten minutes the ground was littered with cute little cadavers.Eventually, the triklopticus developed into beaked scorpion-like creatures with two legs and arms I named the Ornitank.Then they became vaguely humanoid, and when my brain had sufficiently increased in size, I moved on to the Tribe stage and was treated to a cutscene of my Ornitanks discovering fire.I was allowed to give them clothes, because they'd just invented pants, too.This is where the game took on an Age of Empires twist.I had around six tribesmen, all living in a little hut.I could put stuff around the hut and demand that a baby be made (in which case hearts would appear around the hut, an egg would roll out the door, and hatch) and equip my tribesmen with weapons or instruments.I could put them to work hunting or gathering.I made friends with two neighbouring villages, using the power of music, and three attacked me.Three were burnt down.For ever village allied or destroyed, my totem pole got bigger.Before long, my tribesmen were discussing weapons of mass destruction and plotting to take over the world.They grow up so fast *sniff*.I designed buildings to place in my city in such a way as to increase my income and built an armada of tanks, planes, and ships (also custom designed) to conquer other cities.I gave my Ornitanks new clothes that were slightly more "civilised" (among the options I could have chosen was a large blonde moustache) and discovered that the Creature Creator had a "create animated avatar" option, so I turned my Ornitank citizen into an animated avatar.After conquering the world, the Ornitanks turned their attention to the stars and inexplicably invented a spaceship that could go between the stars and only take a few minutes doing so (the ship, by the way, is customisable, like creatures, vehicles, and buildings).I made first contact with an alien race that ignored my ship, because they were in the middle of some kind of world war.I sucked one of them up in my tractor beam and dropped him off on my homeworld, for in the Space stage, I am a  very responsible starship captain!I found a spacefaring race that was big and pink with one eye and a freaky mouth, who spoke to me in a high-pitched voice and asked me to eliminate the infect Doughball! to gain their allegiance (apparently Doughball! is misspelt without the exclamation mark) and so after missions from the aliens and my own race (one of which was terraforming a planet) I set up a trade route and an alliance.However, my only complaint about the space age is that after the game spends so long increasing the scale, you end up playing as a captain on a random ship.The best part is going down onto planets that aren't spacefaring and just straight-up abducting people.On top of that, you unlock crop circles and can just zap them onto planets.I kept going to Civilization Stage planets and using the crop circle tool to fuel any alien conspiracy theorists that may/may not exist.And that is how you go from spermdog to galactic god in less than three days.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Let me get this straight, you want me to tell you a review about this game? Whoever you are, you might as well go to the curators, because if you've come for a review on this game, you've come to the wrong place. However, if you have come for an outstanding chocolate chip cookie recipe, you've come to the right place.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Ingredients1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter3/4 cup packed dark brown sugar3/4 cup sugar2 large eggs1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract1 (12-ounce) bag semisweet chocolate chips, or chunks2 1/4 cups all-purpose flour3/4 teaspoon baking soda1 teaspoon fine saltDirections1. Evenly position 2 racks in the middle of the oven and preheat to 375 degrees F. (on convection setting if you have it.) Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone sheets. (If you only have 1 baking sheet, let it cool completely between batches.)2. Put the butter in a microwave safe bowl, cover and microwave on medium power until melted. (Alternatively melt in a small saucepan.) Cool slightly. Whisk the sugars, eggs, butter and vanilla in a large bowl until smooth.3. Whisk the flour, baking soda and salt in another bowl. Stir the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients with a wooden spoon; take care not to over mix. Stir in the chocolate chips or chunks.4. Scoop heaping tablespoons of the dough onto the prepared pans. Wet hands slightly and roll the dough into balls. Space the cookies about 2-inches apart on the pans. Bake, until golden, but still soft in the center, 12 to 16 minutes, depending on how chewy or crunchy you like your cookies. Transfer hot cookies with a spatula to a rack to cool. Serve.5. Store cookies in a tightly sealed container for up to 5 days.For a Rocky Road Bar:1. Lightly butter a 9 by 13-inch baking pan. Make the batter as per cookie recipe and fold in 1 cup chopped walnuts along with the chocolate chips. Spread batter in prepared pan. Bake until the edges are light brown and the batter sets, about 45 minutes. Cool slightly and cover surface with 4 cups marshmallows and 1 cup chocolate chips. Broil at least 8 inches from the heat until marshmallows turn golden brown, about 2 minutes. (Keep an eye on the marshmallows, and turn the pan frequently--they go from golden to char in a wink.) Cool, cut and serve.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												I like game, but beware EA didn't put a whole lot of effort into this game and it crashes rampantly. I highly suggest you save very often or else you'll end up like me and be into the tribal stage when your game crashes and whisks away all your progress down the drain. EA dropped the ball so much that apparently there isn't even an autosave function. This game crashes so much and personally i don't think I'll ever be playing it again. The game itself is very fun as you get to guide the evolution of your species from a single cellular organization all the way to space faring god. EA made a lot of promises about this game that they didn't deliver. So pretty much standard EA behavior.Pros:+ Engaging gameplay+ Enjoyable & somewhat diverse scenarios+ Diversity among creature creations+ Looks good for something made in 2008+ Lots of unique body parts to chose from+ Species specialization (e.g. carnivore, omnivore, herbivore)+ Different creatures/species have different "voices" (diversity of creature communications)+ Decent job explaining functions of everthing through all stagesCons:- Stages of evolution rather short- Space stage the longest stage (Dispropotionate compared to other stages)- Cannot continue to gain the evolution points to unlock body parts once you complete a stage- Only real option once completing a stage is advancing the evolution- Rather odd taking over planets in Space stage with your single ship- Actually rather odd doing everthing in the Space stage from your single ship- Rampant crashes- No autosave feature- Very few save slots for different worlds- Too few stages of evolution- Almost zero interaction available during Space stage with nonspace faring civilizations

content:
Posted: March 22
												This game is too quick in terms of progression from cellular organism to space-faring creature. Once you get to space, it's the same shake-and-bake colony making: find planet suitable for life, terraform, colonize, and... do it all over again!In other words, once you get to the "end-game" portions of the game, it ends up being very repetitive and boring. Given that EA's servers for the game are also apparently dead, and there being no Steam Workshop at the time of this writing, you don't get to share with others.Basically, the game's missing key features now, there's no support for it, and the DLC content where your space captain goes on adventures is so clunky and buggy, I can't recommend this game anymore.If the game is ever on sale, it might be worth picking up if you've never played it before. Don't get me wrong; the game is fun, it's just that the fun doesn't last after you've done 2 or 3 civilizations.The verdict: this game might be worth $5 if you find yourself playing with character creation screens way too long. Otherwise, spend your hard-earned cash elsewhere.

												This game is amazing. It sparked my creativity when I was young and still finds a way to inspire me today - this game is awesome.I have bought this game about 3 times.Once when the game came out, another after moving houses and losing the CD, and finally (the latest purchase) on Steam. I have countless hours on this game (I mostly play Creepy and Cute DLC; so it wont be showing many hours here).I would recommend to everyone. Especially any parents who want to kick-start their child's creativity.PROS:- Goofy, funny, and entertaining game.- Hours of gameplay and replayability.- Simple and easy to learn controls.- Teaches how civilizations begin and develop (in terms simple enough for youngsters to learn)- Teaches basic biology.- Allows anyone to develop and/or increase their creativity.- Many references to sci-fi movies.- Made by the legend himself: WILL WRIGHT. (Bless his soul)- $15CONS:- May turn your child into a creative freak. Just saying. - No longer supports online functions (from what I know)- The last stage of the game; Space Stage, can be a little overwhelming for youngsters.Bonus con:- No Spore 2 :(

content:
Posted: April 1
												I've played the game for, I think, 1000 hours when I was younger, but on a non-Steam-version. I've never had the DLCs.Now I bought Spore and all it's DLCs on Steam-Sale and started to play again. It's such a great game, but also has some flaws. The idea of Spore is AMAZING!But sadly in some stages, the developers didn't put enough effort in it. I think the most developed stage is the last one, where you can travel the whole galaxy. It's amazing how big the galaxy is and I loved terraforming planets to make them able to be inhabited by creatures or to enlarge my empire. I've also always tried to get friends of the Grox (biggest empire in the Space-stage), or even trying to beat them (I've never beaten them, it's too difficult...)The second most developed stage is the second one, where you can develop you own creature, communicate with other ones and explore the planet. The other stages, I have to admit, are a little short, especially the first one, where you are only a cell. It's so much fun to create species, there are many body-parts and many possibilities to combine and even more with the DLC "Creepy and Cute". But Sometimes you wish for even more body-parts, maybe some more exciting, or that there are other possibilities for putting them on you species. For example, making things bigger, having scarier mouths, and beeing able to put more parts on your species body than you are allowed now. That's why there are many mods, that make the creating of species much more interesting and sooo great. Go to Youtube and serach for "Spore creations" and you'll know what I mean. I'd love to see a Spore 2 where all those flaws are fixed and the developers really put effort in. Many people would probably buy this because they had so much fun with the first one. But sadly after, I think, 9 years, they probably won't develop a Spore 2 and we have to keep playing the fist game. Even though Spore is not the newest game anymore, you should give it a try, because it really can be fun.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Spore is an interesting, different take on the classic god-type genre of games. You begin as a single cell organsim, happily eating (plants or other organisms, or both!) and eventaully running away or fighting other organisms. As you eat, you gain DNA, which is used to modify your creature, from eyes to appendages used to attack others or defend yourself, and other some modifications that do not require DNA, such as enlarging or reducing the size and shape of your creature, enlongating or shortening your spine, even individual segments of your spine! After you consume enough DNA, you will be able to "find a mate" and change anything you like about your creature, including color, color patterns and layers of color and patterns, and anything else you can imagine. Really, the whole point that Spore really drives home is that your creations are only limited by your imagination. Once enough DNA and parts are gathered you can "evolve" to the next stage of evolution, in this case, evolving legs. Once you crawl out of the primordial soup and make landfall, you will have a nest for your species to stay in, and the real adventure begins. You will meet other species and decide if you want to befriend them through either "Impressing" them through song and dance and whatnot, or kill them into extinction. In the next stage of evolution you have a third option to send them gifts, which they may or may not accept. Each decision you make affects the outcome of your creature. Befriending tribes gives you abilities to make it easier to befriend other species in the future, as does killing them, or gifting, the economic solution. Whenever you successfully befriend, or kill a species, you will be rewarded with new parts to help evolve your creature. Many of these at this stage have actual benefits, such as arms with hands that have sharp claws, which will aid you in taking down some of the tougher species, or other parts that boost your ability to sing, dance and otherwise impress other species. As with the previous stage, once you have collected enough DNA through befriending or conquering species, you will advance to the next stage of evolution, Tribal. (NOTE: When you finish creature stage, before you advance to tribal stage you will be given one last chance to change your creature in any way you see fit. Once you enter tribal stage, NO MORE CHANGES CAN BE MADE TO YOUR CREATURE.)The tribal stage is arguably the most difficult stage because you really have to begin managing your resources. You have to gather food to feed your tribe, and plenty extra if you plan on gifting to other tribes. You have a village and as with the previous stage, instead of parts, you have buildings in your village that will assist your tribe in your goal. At this point it is a good idea to settle on whether you plan on being a war-mongering military society, a happy-go-lucky religious society (you still sing and dance to befriend other tribes, but in the next stage you basically convert new species to your religion in order to become allies) or an economic powerhouse (in the near future, capable of purchasing entire star systems). Once you have  enough allies or conquor enough tribes, you advance to the next stage, Civilization.Civilization stage is much like the creature stage, in that it opens up the game into a new level of depth and this time, micro-management. You will discover Spice, the source of all income, and mine the various spice gysers near and far to increase your income (which replaces DNA) and go crazy with creation. Much like your original creature, you can choose from a preset list from Maxis, or if you signed in at the beginning of the game (or at any time for that matter) you can use or modify any creation by any person who has played Spore. Of course, you can also create your own from the ground up, including a Town  Hall, a Factory, Houses, and Entertainment buildings. You can use these in city planning to create a well-balanced city. Too many factories will boost spice processing, but make your city unhappy and easily susceptible to religious attacks, which are much more effective against unhappy cities. Too many entertainment buildings will make your city happy, but your spice production will suffer. You will learn the proper balance with time, experiment and try different things, which is what Spore is all about! Anyway the objective of this stage is to destroy or ally yourself with other rival factions of your species, which has become the single most dominant sentient creature on your planet. Of course you can also establish trade routes with rival cities and eventually be given the option to purchase them, making them as much yours as a city you started with. Again, eventually you will destroy or ally yourself with all the rival factions on your planet, and advance to the final stage, Space.This is by far and away the most fun stage in the game, and once you reach space stage with one species, you can start a new species at any stage (Cell, Creature, Tribal, Civilization, or Space) any time you wish. Your species has advanced enough to begin space flight! From this point, the universe is your oyster! The same ways you haved allied yourself, purchased, or conquered others until now remain the same, although, remember that at least in the beginning of space stage, your species exists on but one planet, whereas other species you meet will be spread across several planets and even start systems! If you want an accurate scope of just how huge this game is, zoom out from your planet, to your start system, complete with other planets, to your local star system cluster to eventually the entire galaxy. Every start system, every planet you see you can visit! You can establish colonies on new worlds to expand your empire, meet new species and decide how to deal with them, do missions for them, hunt for valuable artifacts, and even terraform planets from T0 (No atmosphere, very difficult to sustain a profitable colony) to a T3 oasis, with several booming colonies, ripe for the picking with all different kinds of Spice! From this point you can do whatever, go wherever, whenever you want!All in all, if you like creative freedom, an explorative nature, and want to build your own galaxy spanning empire from a single celled organism to the most powerful species in the galaxy, this game is for you! (On a side note, Spore and Spore Creepy and Cute Parts Pack are completely compatible with Windows 8.1)

Posted: November 29, 2015
												EA and Origin accounts made since 2013 DO NOT connect to spore. User created content is unviewable. EA knows about this and has been sitting on this since July of this year. You also cannot create a new account.Of course I didn't know about that til after the fact, at least you can be an informed consumer.EDIT:Was directed to a forum post to fix the issues I was having. It worked! http://steamcommunity.com/app/17390/discussions/0/490123938445529635/#p2Kudos to KoolAidtheRedDespite that, it doesn't excuse EA making things extremely difficult not only to find out what is wrong, but getting around to fixing it. In the end I'd say go ahead and get this game if you only want half the functionality or if you have the tech-savy to fix it.

												In the pitiful technical state this game is in, I can not recommend it. The early game phases and the creature creator might be nice and all, but it doesn't help that the game has a tendence of crashing whenever a cutscene plays. Of course, one could regularily save the game, but at least in my case, the game doesn't actually save my progress and always resets to the same point. number of helpful: 14 of 24 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												I bought the Spore Complete Pack on sale for 12.47, and I still wish I hadn't wasted the money.  I remember playing the game way back when and it was quite fun, a decent game overall.  But.... it's EA.. I should've known better to think it was really given any REAL effort.One mistake, I'll admit, was my own.  I didn't realize that the game didn't have any autosaving, and you had to save manually.  So when the game crashed, I lost every bit of the game that I'd been playing.Of course, the fact that having my internet go out for a few seconds caused the game to crash... I hadn't expected that to happen.   Nor did I expect to have to create an origin account for the game.   Nor did I expect to have to spend a half an hour getting it to reset my password because every time it accepted a password when I tried to login it said invalid password. ((luckily I was finally able to get a password that worked by saying something derogatory to the company in it.. they had no problem letting that go through it seems, just not a NORMAL password)).  Nor did I expect to have to reboot my entire computer just to be able to log into their servers.   The issues are plenty, and now that I've already spent money on it, I've seen quite a few other people on the net that have had problems with it crashing.   Is the game good?   Sure, it can be fun.   But seeing as how EA infrastructure and coding can destroy just about anything.. well.. good luck if you decide to try it.   I hope you have better luck than I.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2012
												Spore is one of the best God Simulators out there. It gives you full control over your creature. Over the very skeleton and skin cells of it. If there were 1000 people playing the game at the same time, you can be sure their creatures will be totally unique. You start as a simple cell. Whether carnivore or herbivore (or omnivore). A few million years later you develop legs and hands. You get a better mouth and eyes, and nose. You become who you want to become. You can have 10 eyes and 4 noses, 6 hands and 1 leg, while your mouth is positioned on your knee. You can do literally anything. There are lots of stages in your creature's life. You become the leader of a tribe. And then you lead a whole civilization. Later you go on the adventure on conquering the endless space with it's magnificent sights. Creative people must play this. It's amazing how complex and beautiful a creature can get. Especially when you remember that you started from a simple cell.10/10

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												Um dos melhores jogos de simulação que já joguei. Joguei muito mesmo quando criança (ele é um pouquinho "old" , mas é gold, certeza). Em comparação a outros jogos, ele tem uma temática diferente. Segue a teoria da Evolução, em que você cria um ser vivo e de tempos em tempos ele desenvolve habilidades e suas proles nascem mais inteligentes. Porém Spore é divido em uma espécie de estágios, em que você simula coisas diferentes daquela espécie que você criou (estágios em que você é só uma pobre célula dependente e vivente na água, depois você já se adapta à terra, depois tem uma família, uma população toda  e por fim um planeta - sim você brinca com a galáxia- ). Com Spore você não fica naquela "mesmisse" o tempo todo como The Sims ( e sim, é da mesma empresa desenvolvedora Maxis). Bom, para não ficar com uma descrição muito subjetiva, segue abaixo um vídeo perfeitamente explicativo. Ele te toma meia horinha mas tenha paciência, porque vale a pena (a não ser que você realmente não goste do gênero). Por fim, é um jogo divertidíssimo, fácil de mexer e gostoso de jogar (com deliciosos efeitos sonoros e uma rotação de câmera divina -não que isso seja muita coisa).Divirta-se e brinque com a Genética do Darwin  :3


YouTube™ Video: Spore : Vale ou não a pena jogar

			Análise Completa + Informações Nerds Extras. Avaliem por favor e Favoritem! Grande Abraço a Todos Vcs! Tudo de Melhor Sempre!

content:
Posted: March 8
												Update! Got Spore to work with Steam now. So ignore hours played here. I've well over 600+ hours with this game since it's release quite some time ago.So Spore is a God game of sorts, which would be ironic considering it focuses mostly on evolution for what should be the meat of the game. Depending on how you play however, it can still be a good chunk. Starting off from a tiny organism in the primordial soup, you work your way up through the food chain by consuming matter and gaining points to evolve new parts to make you more dangerous, defensive or the alpha being in the micro world. Eventually you gain the ability to have the very basic instincts of a sentient creature, growing legs and walking onto land where you proceed to evolve as before in a much larger world. From there you eventually gain a higher thought process and begin displaying the ability to form a cohesive society capable of thinking. From there you move through what's something of a crude cross between an RTS and several janky game mechanics to befriend or defeat other tribes which appear in the world. Eventually moving on to be the dominant species and begin warring with other nations which spring up. You've several ways to dominate the planet, truth be told, the mechanics behind conquering the world are the same for any path really.And then onto the true meat of the game. Space exploration, terraforming new worlds, meeting new space empires and either kill, conquer or buy worlds from them. And then, the steam for this game begins to die down and the fun train slows substantially. Sure, at first exploring the stars is fun, but after awhile it can begin to become more of a chore to hop around space, meeting certain goals and milestones to improve your ship and empire and defending against aggressive or downright hostile space beings. I will say though, it took a long time, but your ultimate goal is to reach the center of the galaxy. I won't say what you find of course, so the truly curious will have to find their way there or just look it up online like a panzy.Now as for the different stages of evolving a creature, a bit more in depth.Just to note, as you progress through the stages you can choose different paths such as herbivore and carnivore which then translate into other catagories later in the game such as industrious, warlord or peaceful. All of which give some special abilities in the tribal, civilization and space stages and also effect how your creatures evolve in what parts are available in evolution.The first two stages, cell and creature, are fairly similar in mechanics in terms of gaining DNA to evolve. The cell stage is very simple, depending on your difficulty, but typically isn't hard to get through at all. Then the creature stage which uses the same mechanics of the cell stage, but on land and much more three dimensional. The game is a bit silly in how to befriend other creatures, using silly but amusing mechanics. Combat is essentially two animals clawing at each other until one or the other is dead. This is where you begin really planning your creatures evolution a bit more. You can shape it's torso, head and any other appendage to your liking, making everything from humanoid bipedal creatures or a giant♥♥♥♥♥♥♥hopping around. Whatever floats your boat or finds your lost remote, weirdo.When it comes to interacting with the world, whether it's combat or communication, it functions quite a bit like an MMO actually. You click where you want to go or use the typical WSAD keys to move around. Hotkeys, 1234 and such will perform actions depending on what you're doing with small cooldown timers. When moving on after you've gotten enough DNA, the camera mechanics and interactions perform roughly the same for the Tribal stage. This is probably the shortest stage there is. You can easily and quickly defeat or befriend other tribes and chances are it'll take about thirty or forty minutes. Operates the same with hotkeys and movement, but more like a badly formed RTS where you can move units around to collect resources and the such.Next is the Civilization stage which is pretty bland to tell the truth. You can design your own land, water and air vehicles in just about whatever fashion you see fit. In terms of conquering, they're all pretty much the same except for trade which allows you to peacefully buy other civilizations land, but to some extent works on the same mechanics. Then you get to the true meat of the game. SPACE. And at first it's pretty amazing with how massive of a galaxy you have to explore. You'll meet a handful of different species near you, explore different planets and stars that you've seen in the sky since you first crawled onto land.Terraforming, now there's a thing. At first it's pretty neat, slowly shaping a world to sustain life, plopping plants and animals to create a stable ecosystem so you can build colonies to populate new worlds. Along with colonizing you can collect a substance found on many planets called Spice. In this time, the most precious substance in the universe is the spice. The spice extends life. The spice expands conciousness. The spice is vital to space travel. Actually, no it's just a valuable trading commodity of different colors and rarity. You can trade spices between different systems and eventually, in most cases, be able to buy the system and aquire new planets to claim as your own.Now things start to sort of fall apart when it comes to advancing. For a bit all these things are a bit of fun and in short bursts, it can be. However after awhile the game becomes tedious and more of a task. The expansion for the game, Galactic Adventures, does add a fairly decent amount to do, but comes across as excessively cheesy and hokey, though I imagine the target audience was a bit younger than most of the people actually playing the game or somebody at Maxis and/or EA was smoking the dank and watching far to many kids shows on Saturday morning. But a fair amount, if not almost half of other missions aren't so bad and involve a combat system which reflects what you would have experience back in the creature stage. Just with lasers and such. It does make for a less tedious but slower method to obtain Sporebucks, though you eventually reach the point where expanding your civilization, which requires massive amounts of Sporebucks to upgrade your ship. Keep it up though and this grind isn't to bad, but then you're left with even less goals to pursue as you look forward to the tedious journey to the center of the galaxy.Oh right, your ship. Almost forgot. So you get to design a space ship of any design at the beginning of the Space stage. It doesn't matter what parts you put on it, as your ships abilities, defences and other functions are unlocked in other ways. So the design is purely aesthetic. Controls are the WSAD setup with your cursor acting as a point of aiming. Combat is usually fairly simple and becomes somewhat routine after awhile. Once you upgrade your ship enough though, combat becomes hardly a challenge and becomes more of a management thing in simply making sure your ship stays fueled and powered up.There's not much else to say here. I will note, I remember this game being hyped up beyond belief and being a great letdown to a lot of people. I didn't feel all that disapointed, but felt there was a much greater goal this game could have accomplished rather than slowly fizzling out in its gameplay late game. I'm sure some people find the tasks entertaining for a long time, but I've found it's better in short bursts in the late game, as just about everything else can be done in a matter of six to ten hours.So is this game with the expansions worth $40(USD)? That's a shaky yes. But if you're not willing, wait for a sale. With that, I am about to hit the maximum amount of characters available to write a rev--

content:
Posted: March 11
												This game was my childhood back when it was popular (Rip Spore community), it will always be my favourite game. You can play god and create your own creatures and play as them through the Cell Stage (Your creature begins its story as a cell in the water), then to Creature Stage (Your creature evolves and grows legs, moves onto the land and becomes either a killing machine or a friendly diplomatic species), to Tribal Stage (Your creature discovers fire and learns to use tools, and thus begins the Tribal Stage where you have to either fight or befriend other tribes to evolve), to Civilization Stage (Your creature's species evolves to the Civilization Stage which is pretty much modern today, much like tribal stage, you must either befriend or destroy every other Civilization on the planet to evolve, but this time you will have a Navy, Airforce, ect), and finally the Space Stage (Yourr creature's species evolves into the Space Stage, the most complicated stage but in my opinion the most enjoyable stage in the game, you have the ENTIRE Galaxy to explore with over 100 other alien Empires to either go to war with, or befriend and trade with. But then once you approach the center of the Galaxy, you encounter an Empire so vicious and deadly they could simply conqure the entire Galaxy with ease if they wanted to, so beware...). The DLC for this game add amazing new content that will improve your game, Galactic Adventures is the best one though ;). On steam i have about 3 hours of playtime with Spore, but at the time i had the game and DLC on disc, and i eventually got them on steam when i recently lost my spore game cases.Rip Maxis

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												After finally feeling I have put in enough time to review this game I want to go a bit in depth. first let's look positive: on the plus side the cell stage made me nostalgic for the eat and row games I played as a young child. The creature stage I found thoroughly fun and enjoyable. The combat is quite simplistic and easy to navigate if your on a full red streak. Befriending creatures was fluid as well but I haven't done all that much. The user interface I found nice and friendly and had no troube navigating menus. The space stage made me feel quite free and I loved it but it definitely had its bad points.The negatives now: the space stage was too long and I ended up choosing a planet not on looks but on what was closest to the centre, it also suffers from bad combat, a huge difficulty spike and monotony. The civ stage was too restrictive and I found boring and I won't go into the god awful village stage.Overall I really enjoyed this game and would definitely recommend it to friends especially if it's cheap it still holds up great and you can be so so creative with it if you have the money buy it for sure.

content:
Posted: March 22
												I actually like this game quite a bit, honestly, though mostly for Nostalgia reasons and the Creature Builder specificallyGood Parts- you can make aliens of your own design and casually Play God- It's pretty cute - the graphics aren't super realistic and thus haven't suffered too bad with aging, at least aesthetically- This might just be a personal thing bcs I'm a sucker for worldbuilding/storywriting but it's fun to sort of evolve your little alien dude(s) into an empire and like,,, make up their history based on what happens- This game is actually moddable, though be warned bcs it involves dropping files Directly into the game's data folder and you can't share creations made with modded parts- It's also kinda fun to just poke around w/ the data sometimes and mess around w/ the Startup Conditions to unlock Hidden Developer Creators (the Flora and Cell Editors, for example)Bad Parts- It gets really, really repetitive after a while- A lot of people (myself included) have a hard time getting the graphics to actually 'function' and register that you've set them on 'High' - I suspect this is because this game is from like just before the 2010's so it might not know how to run on modern hardware. There's a mod/fix for this somwhere if you go googling but i haven't gotten it to work- There's quite a few bugs but *most* of the major game breaking ones have been fixed for ages.- I have no idea if the Steam version of this has the DRM that it started with - if it does this is a Very Bad Part- The online function is ♥♥♥♥ed on the Steam version - you have to register the game with Origin to get it to go online (though fortunately you do NOT have to buy it again - just register the CD key into it and you're good. You also don't have to bother w/ Origin after this and can never touch it again)Despite the negatives outweighing the positives, I'm still gonna mark this as Recommended as it's a pretty fun game I feel.EDIT TO ADD I'd still wait for it to be on sale to buy it - it's an Alright game but $20 USD for the base game + the DLC is quite a lot and when it's on sale it averages to $15 USD for all three items.

Posted: September 8, 2016
												This game is one of the best I have ever played, not only is there infinite customization, each stage is a different type of gameplay, first level (cell) is somewhat like feeding frenzy or agar.io, the land creature stage is a third person adventure gameplay, tribal stage is a strategy game such as age of empires, national stage is like Civ V or most other strategy games, and the final stage (space) is more of an open world, infinite exploration, conquer the galaxy kind of game. Overall, no matter what kind of game you like, you will most likely enjoy Spore.10/10 would conquer universe again

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												As long as you're not expecting a very serious game, this game is great.   It has a variety of modes/stages to play in, starting as a basic Cell, evolving through an early creature stage through to a large space-faring species, with the fate of the galaxy in your, seemingly the only capable hands in the entire galaxy.  It is very light-hearted sort of story, even the biggest villains in the universe aren't that bad, and the game itself doesn't take itself very seriously.  The Creators are pretty robust if you have a good imagination, you could create an entire species that looks like Bart Simpson, or ships that look like giant butterflies, very close to anything you want.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												A long time ago I dreamt of getting this game as a kid, so many years later I finally got my hands on it and it's even more fun than I expected.  Getting to see your creation evolve from a single cell all the way to a galactic ruler is truly a special experience.  I also find that there is a lot of replay value in this game, I always come back to see what kind or route or creature I can make this time.  If you have an active imagination begging to be let loose on a sandbox world and are willing to challenge yourself to work around the constraints nature has placed on you, then this is the game for you.  Even if you're looking for a more relaxing time, there's an evolutionary stage for everyone.  Keep in mind I have no idea what this game was supposed to be and am only judging it from what I got.  Could this game have turned out better?  Yes.  Is it still fun? Yes. Is it worth the price?  Yes.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												This game was awesome right when I started playing it. You start out as a little cell and the gameplay it much like agario in this stage.Then you evolve and grow legs so you can walk the earth in this stage you can either find Parts by roaming the world of extincting a species or allying with them.There is three different ways you can go.You can either be a Herbivore,Omnivore,or a carnivore.The way you pick will effect you for the rest of the game because it gives you special abilitias depending on what you are.Then there is the tribal stage, The tribal stage is where you command you tribe to go and destroy or ally with another village, Either way you pick it will give you either new tools,weapons,or instruments.Then there is the civilization stage where you get to make tanks,ships,and airships. Then either capture,destroy,or ally with all the other cities, you can also send tanks and ships to collect spice. Then there is my personal favorite stage the space stage.In the space stage you upgrade you ship,go through the galaxy allying,fighting, or capturing entire colonies and planets.There is also a species called the Grog that do not trust people.You can also have more than one world.

content:
Posted: March 23
												I wish the game was longer or more complex. Or harder. I'd really love it if you could only make a few changes at any time. Being able to completely change your monster EVERY. SINGLE. TIME is AWFUL.It's a fun game, but it really needs to be taken to a higher level to be what it should have been.I'd be willing to buy into a hard-choices, slow-develepment, restrictive version of this game. By all means, tie-in a creature builder...I don't care about that, but I want the development of my species to be HARD AND PAINFUL.Pros: Easy to useEasy to pick upEasy to win.Allows for maximum creativeity at any point in your developmentCons:So easy that it's got very little replayability, which is nonsense.No natural flow of development - you can delete your character and just make a new one every time you breed.no restrictions that make it FEEL like you're evolving a creature or their cultureNo 'hard mode'.Conclusion:Better for kids with no patience. Anyone with the remotest amount of patience can DESTROY this game without effort.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Started off as a cell that only ate small peices of meat, just nimble cells trying to stay alive in this world. Got to land, evolved into a spider mixed with a scorpion creature that I like to call "Stenhi", striaght outta of Compton. Befriend other species and live in a fluffy teletubby land of peace and happiness, or eradicate them all to the last man, woman, and kindergarten teacher? Murder them all. Why? Because the snake gods demanded blood sacrifices and its not like we were gonna argue. Now enterd the civiliation era, Stenhi with huge tanks and helicopters that served as mobile bases of muderering and oppression. Mostly murderering. Other civiliations not under my rule? I immediately took control, by blowing up everything. Order was mine, citys only filled with houses and factories, no entertainment of any sort, besides The Jackson 5, I was ruling with order. The Stenhi had ruled the planet with order and communism. They had eventually invented the space ship, they soared the stars, met new people. We traded and did missions for them. Then in the end, we murdered each colony, one by one. "Now I am become Death, the destroyer of worlds." -Gary Coleman  Order and communism, all throught the galaxy, I don't know what's to come next, but if anything, we'll just murder it.Oh and I almost forgot, 10/10.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Simply put: this game contains nearly endless amounts of character customization, and that is why I continue to come back to it over and over. Let your imagination be your guide. You can literally spend 100% of your playing time (like I often do, myself) just designing a multitude of different creatures, vehicles (land, sea, and space) and buildings as well. The game reminded me a lot of Black and White, which I used to play near-obessively when I was younger. There's more to the game than just customization and character design, of course. Following the evolutionary story mode itself presents all sorts of interesting scientific, biological, and sociological mechanics. As a gamer, it's the ultimate sense of creative control to supervise and influence a creature's growth and development, along with all the cultural and societal changes that go along with it. It's just so enthralling to raise a creature from infantile stage as a microbe, all the way to a prim-and-proper gentleman of a monster.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18
												This game is basically five very small games in completely different genres strung together by a single graphic style and very loose narrative.Each individual game has very little content or variety and quickly becomes a race to reach the next game and escape from a lack of new things to see or do. This also means that replay value is very limited as the game will proceed in more or less the exact same way every time.The design of creatures, buildings, vehicles etc has very little effect on their functionality, which is mostly pre-determined by arbritrary rules that are never explained. For instance, an aeroplane cannot have weapons that point down, ie; bombers. You can install such weapons but they will not work.Despite references to evolution, the game's progression feels very contrived and gimmicky and the way in which a species progresses feels more like creationism given how the environment has no effect at all, and is the same each time. The only driving forces in the 'evolution' of species here are the player's sense of aesthetics and the game occasionally telling you to add a certain part in order to progress.With no such thing as difficulty or challenge, the game is unlikely to prove engaging except for small children and people who want games to be challenge free.In short, a grand experiment, but a failed one. It is easy to see and admire the ambitions the game developers had, but the actual product is nowhere near being it. There simply is not enough game in this game to justify the price or indeed even live up to what the store page might reasonably lead you to expect.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												I bought this game when it was released in 2006. While Will Wright's original vision of the game was curtailed by EA's desire to rush it out, Spore has a certain charm that I love. When it came to Steam, I decided I needed to buy it again. This and the expansions are really games for people who love to create and create you can! Ships, creatures, builidings, vehicles, planets, missions, and a whole gaxaly's worth of shher fun awaits. It's not a "serious" space sim. You have to go into Spore with a sense of humor. It pays a loving if rather quirky tribute to Star Trek and Star Wars and other franchises - there is a HEAVY Hitchhikers CGuide to the Galaxy vibe in Spore. Now, all of that said, the base game is good, but it really shines with the Creature Cereator and goes into warp speed with GalacticAdventures. The latter expansion features on planet missions. There are both Maxis created and user created missions and they range from cute to quite frantic, violent, fast paced affairs.I realize that Spore received mixed reviews. But bear in mind that these reviews were partly informed by the fact that Will Wright was not given time to complete his vision for this game. This game is a guilty pleasure for me amid all the "serious" games I play.  Spore is more of a huge creative playground and it does it better than Minecraft at least for me.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												I do rather love this game, but I won't recommend it.I remember back when it was still in development and little by little sneak peeks were shown and it looked amazingly awesome... and then when it came out it (like so many other games) had been significantly dumbed down for a less complex more mainstream gameplay. Even so there was (and still is) a huge amount of delight to be had in raising your creatures from single celled organisms, chosing their skills by rewriting their DNA from generation to generation until they become civilized and then developing them into the endgame (space exploration) via technological advances.So why no recommendation?Well for a start the game is just outright unstable. The general instability just doesn't seem to be fixable. Everywhere I looked I found it was just an accepted side effect of running the game. So it will crash. And it doesn't autosave. So you must save often. And if you screw up and save after it's begun breaking it will destroy that save game and make it forever unloadable. It's also been ditched by EA so it won't be being fixed.The actual evolutionary stages (barring the last) are just too plain short. I wanted to spend hours on each stage but you zoom forwards, even if you go the completionist route and stick around until you've done every last thing you can. The combat is not great, the social minigame is read a cue and then press one of four buttons (creature stage) three buttons (tribal stage) oh we got rid of the buttons just click on it already (civ stage)The final space stage is huge and is where you will will either spend most of your time, or where you will get quickly fed up and return to the start to create more creatures. There is literally an entire galaxy to take over including a race of extremely unfriendly borg *cough* sorry, I mean Grox towards to the centre. Your creature, that you poured so much time and attention into is replaced by a spaceship and it all gets a bit meh.... Galactic Adventures does try to address this but not well... (I'll deal with that on it's own though).Initially you will ooooh over the creature creator. Eventually you will be frustrated by it's limitations and the relatively restrictive set of main parts. The inability to set a gender/voice for your creature is most evidenced when you create something female looking and it talks like a brawny guy or something cute and sounds like it's just waiting to eat you for breakfast. There are a huge number of really minor fixes that could have been added to this that would have provided some huge quality of life improvements for this game... but despite them being suggested over and over again when the game's developers were still active, they were unfortunately never addressed.I still love Spore. It holds a very special place in my heart, but I can't recommend it. If you still fancy it despite its issues then you'll probably have a great time with it. I'd love to see a sequel - some of the things that were cutting edge when this came out are much more developed now and it could be awesome... unlikely, but still...

												The game is a great game, at first... My first 9 hours into the game got me hooked, but once i started space exploration, the game got EXTREMELY boring and repetitive. Edit: If I had just bought the spore game itself without the expansions/dlc (which would amount to $5 on sale), then i could say the game was worth it. So my recommendation to you guys would be to just buy the $5 spore game and not the entire package.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												It's fairly upsetting that the game has a limited number of save files to make a standard galaxy for your sessions. With this setup, the only good thing I can see is that you can destroy an empire more than once for self-satisfaction. The endgame is also lacking in that you cannot explore your terraformed and sculpted wonderplanets, so you have to buy this when the game and Galactic Adventures are at least half price. "Create" mode is like a dumbed-down 3D modelling system.This game consist of various other games that are shortened and lacking as much content placed side-by-side, with your stamp all over the 2008 cartoon graphics. So how can I possibly recommend this game?Because this game is satsifying, and it will be satisfying each time you play.Do yourself a favor and don't go on a wiki until you have played one empire until you are content. Then, go find out all the different paths that you missed, and strive to take them in your next game. You can be a malicious herbivore. You can bedemonic in the creature stage and friendy in the tribal stage. You can beg for peace throughout billions of years and make a corrput spice empire. The gameplay is a vessel for the stories you create in your mind, much like Dungeons and Dragons, and if you find it too easy then raise the difficulty. Ignoring what this could have been and seeing what's here is the key to his game. If you enjoy putting time, love, and effort into game creations, are able to set your own goals, and don't want to worship MMO item stats, then you should enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												Well, it's a bit hard to describe this game...I'll use a story.A small cell named "Invictus" is founded on the planet "Magna Victoria." It eats almost everything it can.Invictus goes on to evolve into a beast and causes a mass genocide of other species on the planet.Invictus makes tribes and then finishes its mass genocide.Now for the interesting part.So, with the Invictus species being the only species left, they are massively split between the usual economic, religious, and militaristic. There are only two militaristic states. Purple (me) and Yellow. The purple state and yellow state are constantly at war until finally the purple state takes over the yellow state. Once these wars are over, on the planet's mainland the other states have been conquered by the massively religious Blues. The blue state then immediately declares war on the purples. The purples then rush to conquer the center island to gain aircraft. They gain aircraft and then start to take the mainland. This basically turns into Alexander the Great's conquest of Persia. Basically, a slaughter for the blues. I make every theocratic city bow down to the great purple power. HAIL!Long story short, as space is basically the other half the game, I conquer everything by slaughtering everyone and there's only one species left, which is Invictus. And we lived happily ever after. The end.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												Spore gets a lot of flak for not living up to the expectations piled upon it. It was hailed as the ultimate creation game, building your spieces from the ground up, with many customisation options. And admittedly, it failed at that. But I still enjoy this game for what it is.The gameplay is split into 5 sections, or 'stages'. The Cell Stage, Creature Stage, Tribal, City and Space Stages. Cell, Tribal and City Stages are too short, but fun. The Creature Stage is longer generally, and is where you develop your species. But the Space Stage takes up around 80% or more of the game. Unfortunately, it's really not that interesting. You go around space, finding planets, talking to aliens, killing aliens, and making alliances with aliens. Sounds fun? Not really. It's alright, but extremely repetitive. And as mentioned, it takes up most of the game, with a huge grind to get to the centre of the galaxy. I've never personally finished the game and have no idea how it ends. It's just too grindy. However, it can still be fun for a while.Where the main enjoyment of the game comes from is the creation. It has creators for creatures, vehicles (boats, ground, flying and space), and buildings. While not the most extensive, I have still put many hours into simply making things.Overall, I would give this game a neutral rating if I could, but I enjoy it more than I dislike it, so I'm giving it a positive rating.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
 Spore  I don't know why i love this game so much. Keep in mind that it has a lot of nostalgic value to me, so i might give way too many positive points. Positive:The Cell Stage: It has a great feeling to it! Like in games like Fishing frenzy, you eat and become bigger, until you can eat things that originally were bigger than you. The stage itself doesnt have a lot of depth. You basically eat or be eaten. And i'm fine with that.Also, i really like the thought of  millions of years passing while you create your creature and live. I find that appealing. It does also apply to other stages, like:The Creature Stage: For me, this is definetely the most fun. And the most defining stage. Here you can choose to be: Herbivore, carnivore or Omnivore(both)! Your choice will affect your playstyle and later game.Herbivore: Pretty easy! All you need is to go to nearby trees and bushes to collect food and that's it! But another factor in it is: Befriending others. Since your attack damage is not that high, you can't really kill. And killing wouldnt even benefit you. So, to make friends you need to have higher stats in social than the creature and mimic their moves.Carnivore: The hardest of all 3. You need to hunt others, because you need meat, and only OTHERS HAVE MEAT. This is really straightforward, since you don't have good social skills, better just kill.Omnivore: THE easiest. This is the definition of "doing what you feel like", you have both social skills AND murderous adaptation! Just do what you feel like, but keep looking at the progress bar to stay in the middle.Thoughts: I LOVE this stage! It really makes you feel like you're inside of it! The creatures, meteor showers and even MOTHA♥♥♥♥IN SPACESHIPS. + i don't know why but i really like seeing Epics [huge creatures with a 1000 hp and kills you in one hit. Fun]The Tribal Stage: So, you finished moddeling your creature. As deranged as it looks, it'll stay that way forever. BUT NOW THERE ARE OUTFITS. That's right! You can put outfits which make your attributes greater, for example: a hat, that has 2 COMBAT and 1 GATHERING.In this stage, depending which play style you chose, you play as:The social bloke: The guy who befriends everyone. Yes, your tribe is known to be the FRIENDLIEST on the planet! You bring gifts to meanies and you mimic people with instruments that you build huts to in your tribe place thingy! FRIENDS!The murderous bloke: Everyone is scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of you. You're known to be the most irrational, murderous tribe on the planet! You build huts for weapons, and you destroy other tribe's huts and kill EVERYONE!The whatever bloke: So, you chose omnivore. You're known to be the most irrational on the planet. Sometimes you befriend others playfully with didgeridoos and other times YOU RIP THEIR SPINES OUT WITH AXES AND LIGHT THEIR HOUSES AND CHILDREN ON FIRE WITH TORCHES.Still trying to keep in the middle, i guess.Thoughts: I really like this stage! I find it fun, trying to collect food, tame wild animals and fish!Also, alot easier to kill Epics in this stage. Still pretty hard tho.The Civilization Stage: So, depending on what you chose, it all came to this, which is:If you chose Social (herbivore) you are: A religion civilization!That's right! Your one and only weapon against others is religion! Since you need to capture all cities or you won't advance to the last stage, you need to create your own custom buildings, vehicles! Fun!If you chose Aggresive (carnivore} you are: A militaristic civilization!Yep! Your one and only weapons are...well...weapons! I feel like this is the easiest to play. You pack firepower, and punches. You also need to create custom buildings and vehicles.If you chose the middle one (omnivore) you are: A trade civilization!Yeah! You don't push religion or bullets down people's throats. You collect money, and you just buy other cities! Strangely enough, being omnivore is the hardest in this stage.Thoughts: I also like this one! I love the thought of designing your own vehicles, boats and planes and buildings! I love the thought of being able to follow your own theme or just be incredibly random! Also, this stage is the defining chapter of WHO you are as a civilization. Are you a friendly religion-based society? A murderous bloodthirsty-based society? Or are you rational bussinessmen?The Space Stage: This is it! You're at the top of...well, anything! You're free to do what you want, because after this it won't matter, althought how you played earlier affects how you'll play ti'll the end!Friendly: You get friendly rays and stuffNot friendly: You get lasers and stuffMiddle: You get some advantages in money and buying (i think)Thoughts: I LOVE this stage! Your one and only objective is to: spread your empire! There's almost no choice here tho. You WILL have allies even if you're ♥♥♥♥ing insane. And you'll have enemies if you're even the friendliest person in the ♥♥♥♥ing galaxy! You can go abduct animals! Abduct plants! Colonize planets! Change planet temperature to uninhabitable from habitable, or the other way around! This stage defines your mark on the galaxy!Negative:No multiplayerI absolutely ADORE this game! And if you're wondering whether you should buy this, please just listen to me: YES! YES YOU SHOULD. This is honestly an INCREDIBLY unique experience and i absolutely love it!10/10

												spore is spore. Thats all i really need to say about it at this point.Everyone and their cat knows that spore is at this point. created by the guy who created the totally not popular at all, Sims series. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Spore could have been one of the best games in years. The concept is great, designing each stage with it's own features and gameplay style was an awesome idea, and it's incredibly unique and creative. However, the "final" game just feels unfinished. EA either bit off more than they could chew with the game or just intended to hype it up and then abandon it mid-development as a cash grab. (Since it's EA, I kind of expect the latter). However, it's still a pretty good game if you want something light and easy to play with little siblings (like I did) that allows for a lot of creativity. However, don't expect it to be a great game you keep coming back to once you've finished a single playthrough.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												IF YOU HAVE PROBLEMS RUNNING SPORE:Go to "C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Spore" and find the file called "runme.exe". Right click it and set the compatibility mode to Windows XP SP2.Now go to "C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Spore\SporeBin" and find "SporeApp.exe" - do the same, set the compatibility mode to WinXP SP2.This should now work. I didn't have to do anything on my Windows 10 x64 machine, but I had to do this for my gf's Win8 machine because nothing else would work.Hope this helps!Otherwise - the game is very fun :)

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												In Spore you start off as a tiny cellular organism, and through adaptation and ingenuity make your way through 5 stages of the game, Cell, Creature, Tribal, Civilization and Space. The game features a fantastic creature editing kit, which allows you to make anything you want, be it a 6 headed horse, or a reptilian butterfly who practices shamanism. And with the addition of the Galactic Adventures DLC, you can create and share handcrafted quests and missions with other players! It's awesome, Spore ate up my early years of PC gaming, and I can only hope this review will convince you to buy it!

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												Spore introduces an amazing idea to replicate how life starts off as a single cell, and then evolves to dominate the universe and beyond. The millions (maybe billions) of choices to make in the game, such as creating your creature, making a village hostile or peaceful, or dominating your home planet through military means, is truly amazing. The evolution stages in the game each have their unique touch to it, making the player hooked on to the game for countless hours. Whether its taking down an Epic creature, or making peace with other nations, the game is remarkably fun.10/10

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Before reading please note that this is the first review that i made on steam and that my main language is portuguese so u can expect some grammar errors.~ ***SPOILERS COMING: if u dont want to receive a bucket full of spoilers skip to FINAL DECISON. Spore is a game that represents nature, the evolution of creatures over centuries, basicly it represents how life is created and evolves. In this game u start as a small cell that needs to eat to grow and evolve, u soon realize u need to evolve to hunt and survive other creatures. When u finnaly become the most evolved and the king of the sea u realize that the sea isnt big enough for u now, so u decide that it is time to explore the rest of the world and go to the surface. After your creature has evolved and grown legs u walk into land and your sister and brothers follow u. In order to survive u have to hunt (in case u are carnivorous or omnivore) or go and search for fruit (in case u are a herbivore or omnivore). Many other creatures have also evolved and in order for u to become more intelligent u need to hunt or ally with the other species. Find piles of bones or extiguish a race to get some more pieces that u can use to modify your creaute. The Tribal Stage, in this stage your creature discovers new tools and fire, u are now a intelligent race. As time goes on other tribes will appear, u can choose to destroy them, making use of axes and spears, or to ally with them using musical instruments to impress them. The Civilization Stage, in this stage your creature decides that its time for them to build a great city and then unify your planet using many new technologies (in this stage u can build many stuff, buildings vehicles, etc) u can choose to conquer your rival countrys, use religion to make them join u or make use of economy and buy their lands. The Space Stage, in this stage you are a cadet that is the first of your species to leave the planet and explore other solar systems, many new empires with many religions, tons of other planets with many new species of plant and animals, terraform planets with no life to a paradise with many citys, explore the galaxy and find out what exists in the middle of it.  *******FINAL DECISION*******                                 I played for 49 hours until now and i plan on making the number increase.                                The only real problem that i find in this game is that after u spend some time in the space stage u become very bored.                                U can still search for many new creatures, buildings and vehicles online.                                Make many designs of vehicles and buildings using many decorations and bases.                                Evolve your creature in order to survive.                                This game is based in science about our universe.                                U can also find our solar system in the game :D                                U can change the look of many planets by colouring them or changing their surface.                                Meet many diferent empires (some can be online created races) making missions.                                In my opnion this game is: 8/10.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												I'm not a huge fan of EA games in general. Most of them are quickly made, shotty performance, and more often than not crash for no apparent or fixable reason. However, I do have a soft spot for Spore. Its interesting in the least, though does get quite repetitive. If you're trying to make a specific looking animal, good lucky. The builds are difficult to get just right, and trying to be an ally to several species can be even more difficult. You need to interact with just about every possible sepecies in order to get all the parts for your creatures (especially with the cute and creepy pack). But, that's where half the fun comes in. I never made it very far into the game, because I'd keep restarting to fine tune my one creature. If you're a creative mind, you'll probably end up in the same boat as me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												I have very mixed feelings about Spore even after many years and dozens of hours of gameplay. I owned it on origin when it first came out, and while I enjoyed my time playing it I always felt like it was half finished. Each era has a unique gameplay style which is refreshing and a big part of the appeal, but only the Creature Stage really feels fleshed out at all. All the levels are seriously unbalanced, as well, giving specific traits an incredible advantage or disadvantage.I repurchased the game on Steam when a sale made it cheaper to buy all three (Spore, Creepy & Cute, and Galactic Adventures) than to buy just Adventures for my original copy. It adds a lot to the final stage of the game, which gets repetitive fast, except... it, too, gets repetitive fast. I'm not sure if I just don't have the setting right or whatever, but I'm limited to the same basica missions over and over and over. Perhaps if I could figure out how to connect to community made missions it would be more enjoyable. However, community made objects and creatures in game tend to be a mixed bag, so who knows.HOWEVER, I did introduce my 10yr old nephew to this and he is totally hooked. So, if you're looking for a children's game rather than for an adult, then I would recommend it without reservation. It is the shell of a genius game that was simply never fleshed out - trying to do too much too early in the development of the technology. I would love to see a remake with a focus on story and balanced gameplay rather than just the creature creator.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22
												I remember first playing it back at 2010 when I first heard it was nominated for Game of the Year. The concept of being able to create entire new creatures and species was new to me at the time. And to this day, Spore remains in my opinion one of the best games of its genre, despite its age. It's pretty much the No Man's Sky of its era, but a legit, fun game.TL;DR Version: Better No Man's SkyPros:- Hundreds of hours of gameplay- Unlimited possibilities of creatures to create- Game is divided into 5 distinct stages; each with their own way to play (Space stage being late-game, where you will invest the most time if played correctly)- Still a great game after nearly a decadeCons:- The game is old; in my experience the game is capped at 30 fps with mediocre graphics- Once you reach the space stage, it will get repetitive quickly- Creature creator controls is a bit buggy at times- Needs an Origin account to access online content such as the SporepediaLong version:You know those games where once you start to play, you can't seem to quit? Spore is one of these games, and I have enjoyed every hour that I've spent playing. Gameplay:Due to the freedom of choice that you have, you can try out different ways to play; whether you want to be a warmongering dictator, a money-crazed economist, or a friendly peacemaker, the choice is yours I've had multiple saves, each with a different archetype, and I can assure you that the effort spend is worth it.While on the topic of archetypes, there are 9 total archetypes. Each has their own unique skills and advantages in the space stage. Archetypes are determined by your behaviour in previous stages. For example, if you are aggresive throughout the game, you will get the Warrior archetype which increases you spaceship's health and weapon effectiveness. Note that archetypes are determined after the civilization stage and as you enter the space stage. This means that you can make up a combination of 4 different alignments to determine your archetype. It's hard to explain so just Google it. TL;DR: There are multiple classes which have different skills and advantages.The game is divided into 5 stages: Cell, Creature, Tribal, Civilization and Space. The Cell stage acts as a tutorial and foundation to your game. Here, you will decide how you will playstyle in the Creature stage; be it an aggresive carnivore,a sociable herbivore, or be the best of both worlds and become an omnivore.The Creature stage is where the fun starts. You play as a creature you design and try to evolve to a higher sentience. While doing so, you hunt or befriend other creatures to gain body parts which you could use to alter your appearance and abilities. Here, you finalize your looks and enter the Civilization stage.If the Cell stage is a baby, and the Creature stage is a child, then the Civilization stage is the pre-adolescent. The game suddently changes to a RTS and therefore management becomes essential to the game. You control your units and try to achieve global domination by claiming other cities through various means. Here, it gets harder as you pave your way to the Space stage.As I said before, the Space stage is where you will invest the most time in. You explore the universe, meet new species, gain new allies or enemies, and eventually conquer the galaxy. Here, the game's plot starts to develop (although personally it doesn't really matter). This stage requires the most time and focus as the fights get more intense and quests get more complicated and time-consuming. You'll learn more of the business aspects of the game as you trade your resources for money, realizing that some colonies offer more for the same resource. So get money, get better equipment, and start aiming for space domination.Creation:When it first game out, Spore boasts the abillity to be able to create creature that you like. That is true to a certain extent, but it doesn't stop there. When you reach the later stages, you get to design buildings and vehicles. The creation tool is simple and user-friendly and looks crappy at first. But with enough creativity and skill, you can create a lot of unique creations that looks and functions differently. There's also the Sporepedia, where you get to share yor creations and download others'. Unfortunately, the system is unappealing and frankly, bad. It is horribly crowded and the filters don't really help. It would be better if Steam enabled the Workshop here, although it is unlikely since Spore is owned by EA, and the game pretty much runs through Origin.DLC:For both DLC, the C&C and Galactic Adventures DLC, please refer to their individual reviews on my account.- Creepy and Cute- Galactic AdventuresTL;DR: Both provide decent content but is ridiculously overpriced.Overall:Spore is a great game if you love to create monsters and let your creativity run wild. It is also a great RTS with a lot of content to explore. The space stage, however, may get repetitive. I usually find myself playing the space stage for a few hours before going to the creature creator to freshen up my mind. Despite its age, Spore is a wonderful classing and remains enjoyable even today.Rating: 8/10
