content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												It's fairly upsetting that the game has a limited number of save files to make a standard galaxy for your sessions. With this setup, the only good thing I can see is that you can destroy an empire more than once for self-satisfaction. The endgame is also lacking in that you cannot explore your terraformed and sculpted wonderplanets, so you have to buy this when the game and Galactic Adventures are at least half price. "Create" mode is like a dumbed-down 3D modelling system.This game consist of various other games that are shortened and lacking as much content placed side-by-side, with your stamp all over the 2008 cartoon graphics. So how can I possibly recommend this game?Because this game is satsifying, and it will be satisfying each time you play.Do yourself a favor and don't go on a wiki until you have played one empire until you are content. Then, go find out all the different paths that you missed, and strive to take them in your next game. You can be a malicious herbivore. You can bedemonic in the creature stage and friendy in the tribal stage. You can beg for peace throughout billions of years and make a corrput spice empire. The gameplay is a vessel for the stories you create in your mind, much like Dungeons and Dragons, and if you find it too easy then raise the difficulty. Ignoring what this could have been and seeing what's here is the key to his game. If you enjoy putting time, love, and effort into game creations, are able to set your own goals, and don't want to worship MMO item stats, then you should enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Spore could have been one of the best games in years. The concept is great, designing each stage with it's own features and gameplay style was an awesome idea, and it's incredibly unique and creative. However, the "final" game just feels unfinished. EA either bit off more than they could chew with the game or just intended to hype it up and then abandon it mid-development as a cash grab. (Since it's EA, I kind of expect the latter). However, it's still a pretty good game if you want something light and easy to play with little siblings (like I did) that allows for a lot of creativity. However, don't expect it to be a great game you keep coming back to once you've finished a single playthrough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												spore is spore. Thats all i really need to say about it at this point.Everyone and their cat knows that spore is at this point. created by the guy who created the totally not popular at all, Sims series. Unfortunately the game was hyped to hell and thigns got cut and people got butt hurt...so yeah.The creature creator is hell of a lot of fun. I spent hours just fiddiling with creatures in the game when i owned the original disc. And really, I enjoyed myself throughout the entire game. Though some of the stages were way to short, tribal, & Civ in particular. And the space stage has two irritating as hell issues:Pirates and eco disasters.Think of it like this:You have been hopping from system to system, jumped into a few black holes and traveled for like, 20 minutes. Then you get the message....the message you've been dreading. Your planet has an eco disaster and you need to high tail it all the way back to the system before your planet gets screwed. And of course, if your one ship doesn't do it. everything will fall to pieces.So yeah...cheat your♥♥♥♥♥off in that stage, or download a few mods and everything will be peachy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18
												I remember seeing the trailer for this game on Nick in 2008 when I was 7 years old. Later that year I recieved it for christmas. I had never been more amazed with anything in my life. In case you weren't aware, in this game you guide a creature from it's humble multicellular stages all the way to being a galactic god of sorts. As a child this was super fun to play and I probably would've failed elementary school if my mother hadn't bought a new computer. Anyways, it's 9 years later and this game still totally rocks my a** off. There's an endless array of things to do and with two moderately interesting expansion packs, you might just find the kid in you playing this instead of tending to your worldly responsibilities. Yes it gets criticized for what it's not but that's not really a fair criticism now is it? Witty, far out, and incredible.  10/10

Posted: January 5, 2016
												Spore is a very great game i personally before i got the game i watched around 10 diffrent series on this game such as TerasHD, DanTDM, Aphmou, Mousie, LittleLizardGaming, Bdoubleoo100 and GenerickB. Teras having 5 different series on spore. I've played for nearly 23 hours at the time of creating this and its still entertaining. On the modded side of things the creepy and cute parts pack is not a necesity but its nice to have some lttle peices to have being a cheap-ish price its fine, the Galactic Adventures mod is a must get, after you've played the space stage for a while its a great addition, luckly for me i was able to buy this game for a low price due to the 75% Christmas Discount. I believe this game is well worth the money sadly the error in spore servers makes you opptionally go through a long series of steps to go online, the game overall is great fun and the creativity is too, the player input in to the game is outstanding. At this time Spore is most likely my favourite game. Good bye and good gaming!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Spore could have been one of the best games in years. The concept is great, designing each stage with it's own features and gameplay style was an awesome idea, and it's incredibly unique and creative. However, the "final" game just feels unfinished. EA either bit off more than they could chew with the game or just intended to hype it up and then abandon it mid-development as a cash grab. (Since it's EA, I kind of expect the latter). However, it's still a pretty good game if you want something light and easy to play with little siblings (like I did) that allows for a lot of creativity. However, don't expect it to be a great game you keep coming back to once you've finished a single playthrough.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												Let me ask you a question... Would you like to be god?.... I know you would.... everybody would.... and this game is the reason why!!! but that's not enough, let's dissect it piece by piece:1-PRESENTATION AND GRAPHICSFirst of all, this game looks AMAZING on max resolution, even in MY pc's resolution it looks good, and it's like minimum or something, and the animations are very well done, except when you add too many legs to your creature and they get web'd, it's safe to say the animation depends if your creature is designed the way they want it to be.2-SOUNDTRACKThis game's soundtrack is VERY atmospheric, it has a "wonder" feel to it, the tracks aren't even that good, they just fit the feeling of spore, it's very hard to describe.3-GAMEPLAYThe game consists on Creation Mode and Story Mode, in creation mode, you create your creation created on the Spore creature creator.......... I'm proud of that sentence..........in story mode you ALSO create your creature, but this time, you go from a cell to a space king, with your own adventure...4-CONCLUSIONThis game is fantastic, only one thing... when you get to space stage... Move on... the game gets boring in space stage, unless you try it out and like it, i personally don't, but i completely recommend you try this game if you're a fan of sandbox games, wth that said, i give SPORE...a 6/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6
												This is an amazing game! From a single-celled organism to a space colonizer, you control a species (Individual animal in Cell,  Creature, and Space stages) or you are a leader for the species (Tribal and Civilization stages). Either way, you can design your species, liken whether they are an herbivore, carnivore, or omnivore, and their buildings (From the Civilization stage to the Space stage). It can take a while to get through the game. However the game rewards you for speed-running (I didn't, but I still completed the Creature and Tribal stages in less than an hour each) with ACHIEVEMENTS! I honestly won't tell you more, because you need nice surprises throughout the WHOLE GAME! I do recommend this game very much!

content:

												Don't take it from the time I've spent playing this on Steam, I've played this game for hundreds of hours since it originally came out. Now, this game got a lot of flak because it didn't meet the standards the trailer left for it. Now, while this is true, I still think it was great for what it is worth. A lot of the games feel like minigames, that is true, but it is still a lot of fun, especially once you reach the Space Stage. Traveling the entire galaxy is something I have always wanted from a game.  As well, I have spent hours simply creating new creatures; it's so fun!I'd say this game is worth your money, despite what you would hear.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2013
												The moment you get your hands on this game, you will not want to walk away from it... well, at least not for another couple of play-throughs. As with any sandbox-like game, gameplay will become repetitive, but that doesn't make your first experience with Spore any less memorable. There have been times when I've allowed Spore to sit and collect dust for months, but whenever I get the urge to play it, I'm glad that I have it, and the cycle of excitement begins anew. Spore is a must-have for any casual gamer, and certainly recommended for anyone who has yet to try it.

												It's fun, but there's a catch. Whenever you think you're doing really well, it crashes. You think you're fine the first time. All games auto-save nowadays. Wrong. Not Spore. I'm sure there's a mod for it (haven't actually checked) but the fact that the Devs didn't already put in an auto-save feature actually ruins the game for me. All in all it's super fun and definitly worth buying. I'm just not happy about the auto-save feature, or lack-there-of.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
												This game catches alot of flak for trying to do too much at once, and failing to flesh it's components out enough. I personally didn't mind that all that much. I treat it like the evolution sandbox that it is. Honestly the most fun I've had playing this game is from cell stage to the beginning of space age. I feel like while space age gameplay is the most complicated and expanded upon, it's also the most boring. I loved making the creatures, and roleplaying evolution. Do yourself a favor. Don't completley reconstruct a creature in a differing shape and with completley different better parts. Think about how it would ACTUALLY evovle, and try to keep yourself within those limits. Make your own story for your race. Why do their buildings have spikes on them? Are they agressive? Do they wear armor on the weak spot on their neck? If you do this I promise you the game will mean much more to you.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												Loved this game when I was a kid. Even with the expansions now, it still has its issues - lack of complexity in all the game modes besides creature and space, no female voices for your creatures, tedious gameplay. And yet, there's something charming about raising your little cell from a tiny bacteria all the way to the conqueror of the galaxy. You can try to make your creature follow some sort of realistic evolution, or make phallic creatures and laugh as the engine makes them wobble around. Though honestly, go with the first one - the game leaves a lot to be desired, but you can patch those holes with your own creativity. (seriously stop making dickmonsters please.)

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												Don't take it from the time I've spent playing this on Steam, I've played this game for hundreds of hours since it originally came out. Now, this game got a lot of flak because it didn't meet the standards the trailer left for it. Now, while this is true, I still think it was great for what it is worth. A lot of the games feel like minigames, that is true, but it is still a lot of fun, especially once you reach the Space Stage. Traveling the entire galaxy is something I have always wanted from a game.  As well, I have spent hours simply creating new creatures; it's so fun!I'd say this game is worth your money, despite what you would hear.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
												This game catches alot of flak for trying to do too much at once, and failing to flesh it's components out enough. I personally didn't mind that all that much. I treat it like the evolution sandbox that it is. Honestly the most fun I've had playing this game is from cell stage to the beginning of space age. I feel like while space age gameplay is the most complicated and expanded upon, it's also the most boring. I loved making the creatures, and roleplaying evolution. Do yourself a favor. Don't completley reconstruct a creature in a differing shape and with completley different better parts. Think about how it would ACTUALLY evovle, and try to keep yourself within those limits. Make your own story for your race. Why do their buildings have spikes on them? Are they agressive? Do they wear armor on the weak spot on their neck? If you do this I promise you the game will mean much more to you.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												Spore is a fun little game where you begin as a single celled organism. As you progress you collect DNA from killing other animals or simply eating leftovers and plants. The further you go the more parts you collect and from there you are able to completely customize your own life form. Eventually you move onto land and begin the process of becoming a more advanced form of life. Soon your species begins to spread across the globe as your species acheives dominion over all others. Not long after that your species becomes civilized and builds cities and more advanced tools for war.Then comes the space stage... and from there it sucks. I only reccommend this game because everything before the space stage is so much fun. I give it a 4 out of 5.

												When this game went on sale, I was so stoked for it. I really, REALLY wanted to play this one after playing the DS game quite a while back. $12 for the entire bundle that would normally cost $50? What could possibly go wrong?Oh. Oh. So very, very much.I'm just going to clear something up right now: the 8.1 hours of gametime I have logged at the time of this review were all continuous.It started out simple enough --- start off as a cell, eat food, and get bigger. Eventually I got to land, and all was well. I decided to play the friendly route. I played as an herbivore and tried to befriend every species I came across. Didn't ALWAYS work, but 90% of the time.Then came the tribal era. At this point, somewhere I snapped. A screw or two came loose and I went on a murderous rampage, sending my Gryphon people to slaughter every other tribe. At this point I was still semi-sentient and had to consistently check to make sure I wasn't hallucinating, and that what I was playing was actually happening, for real, on my screen.When the civilization era hit I may as well have been in a damn coma. I was mentally dead and before I knew it I'd captured every city through military force, even mercilessly killing the last empire that was supposed to be my ally.Next thing I knew I was in a spaceship, shooting lasers at my own kind because they were "infected".Eventually I was able to leave this game's grasp. But not without some serious self-reflection later.I began peaceful, only to deteriorate into a murderous psychopath who slaughtered every other existing race before turning on my own, ultimately becoming the highest form of dictator.10/10 would kill 99% of the planet again.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												This game represents itself, from being a cell with not much to do, to exploring the galaxy with infinite possibliites. The actual "campaign" is split into five stages: Cell, where you eat everything to grow; Creature, where you become friends with other species or kill them off; tribal, where you become allies with other tribes (or conquer them); civilization, where you buy buildings for your cities to increase income, then ally yourself or become enimes with other cities; and space, where you roam the galaxy terraforming, colonizing, waging war, establishing relations, and more. It ultimetly combines arcade, adventure, strategy, and sandbox gameplay, topped off with a system of deciding whether you're a carnivore, social, economic, etc. Not to mention, the creativity is amazing. You can create your own cells, creatures, buildings, cars, boats, planes, and even spaceships, with a ton of creativity. Overall, I think you should get this game if you don't have it, and although 20 dollars seems expensive, the game is worth its price.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												I played this game for years and decided to try it again out of pure nostalgia when I saw what a disaster No Man's Sky is. Spore has so much more to it, is full of options and paths ans all the small bits and details that few games can bring together. Ofcourse it has it's flaws, and the way EA treated it made players furious with the game in the beginning, but after years of being on the market it kept it's value. People still play it and those new to it can be assured to find a wonderful experience which is more obvious when looking back from Space Stage rather than at the moment of playing previous stages. Cell Stage is short and minimalis, just like the life and tiny world of a cell is, while Creature stage is much greater in scope and gameplay. Tribe Stage and Civilisation Stage are somewhat similar while feeling unique, but shorter that Creature Stage. And then there's the Space Stage, the longest journey in the game, a stage as big as the Milky Way galaxy in both size and scope.If you re disappointed with No Man's Sky and you wanna get your space-game fix, don't pass up Spore.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												I've had this game since the year it released, and I can safely say I didn't get bored with it for a very long time. After taking a year-long break, I've come back to the game and it still entertains me. The creation system is good and complex, and playing through the story is fairly entertaining as well. The only thing I can say about this, is get the complete pack, or at least Galactic Adventures because the latter especially makes the game far more entertaining. The only real downside to this game I can think of personally is that the community is not anywhere near as active as it used to be, but they seem to be working on fixing that by bringing back featured creatures and such.Oh wait, I can think of one actual complaint.Maxis, if you're reading this:GIVE US BOT PARTS. Even if its a DLC, because very few people have them but very many people want them. The promotion was cool but nowadays its impossible to get them without modding, which you can not do with the steam copy as far as I know. I am a long time player of this game. I have multiple copies of the disc version and all its DLCs, and I rebought the game on steam recently to show my support. There is an audience and potential for this game to make a comeback if you really put in the effort to try.Thank you for reading my review. Have a nice day.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
												Spore is a game where you evolve a species from a tiny cell (Microbe) into a space dwelling empire, a great concept, and overall, a great game! I played Spore quite a while back, right when it came out, I played it for hours on end. I decided to come back to it 3 years later, and wow, it's still a really addicting game, (44 hours? That's not much. Well, I've played on the Creepy And Cute expansion for a lot more) they include multiple types of gameplay, as in Cell stage, you work your way up and grow by eating until you are large enough to walk onto the shore. Creature stage is slightly different, as it's a bit more open world with more options and possibilities. You can either socialize or hunt down creatures in a nest. Creature stage also opens up to the Creature creator, with far more parts then Cell stage that will help you adapt and survive to eventually make it to the top, eventually leading you to Tribal Stage. In this Stage, you take control of your tribe members, socializing or killing off other competing tribes. Tribal stage also leads to equipment to put on your creatures. Once you defeat or ally with 6 of the tribes, you head off to Civilization stage with 3 unique ways of gameplay. This stage you take control of cities, by either capturing them with military might, buying them with trade routes, paying them enough for them to eventually ally with you, or forcing your peaceful beliefs on cities. This is where Spice begins to take an important role, when you capture these spice geysers, it gives you income, which allows you to build your cities and create vehicles. Once you get world domination, it leads you to a casual Space sandbox. This game is all around a really amazing game, I have to give it a good 9/10. Totally worth the money.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												A fun game, if it doesn't quite reach it's potential.Will Wright's Spore started out as a grand experiment in evolution, equal parts game and educational tool. When it saw release, fans of Maxis were dissapointed to find many of the touted features had been stripped out (including an entire stage) and everything given a cartooney makeover, seemingly in an attempt to replicate "The Sims" success with the casual market. It seemingly worked as Spore was a very popular game.Despite this, what we have is still an intiresting game. There are five mini-game like stages where the early goals are to survive and evolve while eventually growing your culture.CELL STAGEYou start out as a microbe and must feed either by hunting other microbes or grazing algae. intermittently throughout, you can find a partner and evolve your species. This is done through the "creature creator" where you can attach various body parts such as claws, defensive spikes or pretty much anything you want. More and more parts are unlocked as you collect "evolution points" throughout the stages. The creature creator is the easily the best part of this game and the amount of customisation is staggering. There is also some strategy as various body parts have different atributes attached to them and can effect the type of build you are going for.CREATURE STAGEOnce your creature is large enough, it grows a pair of legs and climbs out onto land. Gameplay is much the same, keeping your species alive and evolving but now you can interact with other creatures as you try to grow your brain size. The "creature creator" options expand enormously. In my opinion this is the best stage of the game.TRIBAL STAGEHaving achieved sentience, your species forms a primitive tribe and must either go to war or ally with other tribes. As you are now a society, your biology is locked and can no longer evolve. Instead of evolving your creatures, you can now deck them out with basic tribal outfits and jewlery.CIVILIZATION STAGENow that your society is more advanced, you have a home city where you can design the various buildings and veicles. Your goal now is to subjugate the various races on your planet by either warring with them or converting them to your religion. This is in my opinion the least intiresting stage, thankfully it is also the shortest.SPACE STAGEHaving conquered your planet, your eyes now turn towards the heavens. You design & build a ship and explore a vast galaxy. You make trade deals and alliances with other races and try not to go to war with the games villains, the Grox. You can visit hundreds of worlds, establish colonies, terraform planets, even abdust creatures from one planet and seed them on another. It really is quite complex but can be overly repetative. There are various optional objectives, reaching the highest rank, conquering every other race, reaching the centre of the galaxy, but there is no real end-state so you can continue indefinately.There is no way all the creatures and plants can fit onto the disc so the other really notable feature is that when connected to Maxis' servers the creatures designed by other players can populate the various worlds.If you haven't noticed, the gameplay in each stage seems to follow a pattern, either befriend or kill all your competition. There really isn't much variation between these stages. There was also a stage cut from the game during development process. Set between cell & creature, the fish stage would act as a bridge from sea to land.While Spore is not the game it could have been, it's still worth the €15 asking price for the creature creator and space stages alone.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												[TLDR: What No Man's Sky wanted to be.]This is the game that, in my opinion, kick-started the whole space craze that's been going on in gaming recently, and hilariously enough, it's still got it even after all these years. As games such as Elite Dangerous and No Man's Sky continue to build upon the space aspect, that seems to be all they focus on: space. This game, with its impressive expansion "Galactic Adventures," has it all, from ground-side missions to space truckin'. And that's just the tip of the iceberg!+Has a certain goofy charm to it akin to the Sims.+Even for today's standards, the game looks pretty great.+Each stage of evolution has its unique gameplay style and is a ton of fun.+Many different paths to choose from; become a destroyer of worlds or a protector of all life.+Customize just about everything, from the creatures theirselves to the cities they live in.+Make alliances and enemies throughout your journey to dominate the galaxy.+Side quests, especially with Galactic Adventures, make the game more varied and interesting.+Planets are varied and are completely manipulatable.There are, however, a few hiccups here and there:-Complexity meter can sometimes be too restrictive.-Some animations on custom creatures can be awkward.-Beginning evolution stages can be very short and shallow.-Allies in space stages can be a bit too needy.-Cartoony-ness may put some people off.Thankfully, however, most of these issues can be ironed out with mods! That's right, mods exist for this game, such as Platinum Spore, Titanspore, and Dark Injection, which adds in the parts from Darkspore, this game's darker and edgier spin-off.I cannot recommend this game more to people who want their space fix, and, while I'm uncertain if the online component of the game even functions anymore, there are plenty of awesome creations for people to go out and download, especially the Galactic Adventures missions!<Final Verdict: Worth the Buy, Worth your Time!>

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												Spore.The game where you can dive into a world of things to explore. You may find, dark, scary things such as bones the size of a mountain, and creatures the size of so roaming the planet's surface.Lightning strikes down upon us, setting our village to flames. It reminds me of when I first saw that fire. I named it the red flower.An object, completely circle towered above our feeble attempts to retreat. Bright red lights shone down onto my friends I had known since the beginning of my life. I looked away. I watched as everything and everyone I knew died in front of my eyes. It was horrible.I somehow managed to survive that horrid day, I found the survivors and rebuilt our civilisation. We discovered many things that would aid us in our lives. We grew stronger and conquered our enemies.We discovered a large metal cylinder inside one of our opponents buildings that were not nothing but dust. The cylinder opened, and I remembered. I remembered the day that my friends died. It was that flying monster, that horrible, horrible thing that killed us all. But I had to explore it.Night was falling, and we had defeated every living thing that could possibly be a threat. No mercy. Just death. A thick fog blinded us as we made our way back to the spaceship. It towered above us yet again. The rest of my fellow friends stood beside me, and crowded around the ship. I opened the hatch and walked inside. I felt the eyes of many people watch closely as I disappeared into the darkness of the spaceship.A whole new world surrounded me. It was amazing. I flew further out of the planets gravitational pull. Out of the solar system. I gazed over the white pretty lights sparkling and twinkling in front of me.Then I saw it. Another person to defeat.The enemy spaceship wizzed around me as I tried to find a way to fight back. BOOM! A missile hit the ship. The spaceship fell off course, and was aiming straight back to my planet. Those red lights punctured the ship and cut it in half.I flailed helplessly as I was pulled out of the spaceship, still falling back to the planet. I realised that I was about to die. Tears fell down my cheeks as I choked without the oxygen I needed to live. I hoped I would pass out before I hit the surface of our barren planet that was ripped of resources by us.I waited for my death. Closer and closer the planet came. Helplessly falling. Down and down. I remembered everyone I loved and knew, and felt sorry. I should of fought with them against the spaceship. Instead of being a coward and running. I should of fought, and not care if I died. At least I would go down as a hero.Another single tear fell down my left cheek, and I hit the ground.10/10, I really enjoy exploring new planets and species. I love the first stage, it's like agar.io!

												Even though this game is old, it shall always stay gold. No other game comes close ot what this game offers, or takes on such a challenge with all the mixed genres inside of it. A very fun and family friendly game, and is very creative. The only thing that could ever come close to this is a sequel. You start as a smal amoeba, and conquer your way to the top of the food chain, grow a brain, adventure land, form tribes, hunt, gather, build empires, destroy them, and even explore space as far as you want. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who hasn't played this.-I don't have ebola

												Fun game, quite funny. You can create an alien species, starting from a cell in the ocean to going into space travel. Every animal.. er.. creature you make will turn out weird. Never try to make an existing animal in this game, it will turn out to be an abomination. In the creature stage, your.. things many weird noises. You can make friends with other creatures on this planet or you can kill them.There are many solar systems and planets that are all different. You're technically in one giant galaxy (Yes you can find earth), and you can go to the center, but there's an evil empire taking over the core.Fun game, every creation I make, from the animal to the buildings and vehicles, makes me laugh.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												Spore.The game where you can dive into a world of things to explore. You may find, dark, scary things such as bones the size of a mountain, and creatures the size of so roaming the planet's surface.Lightning strikes down upon us, setting our village to flames. It reminds me of when I first saw that fire. I named it the red flower.An object, completely circle towered above our feeble attempts to retreat. Bright red lights shone down onto my friends I had known since the beginning of my life. I looked away. I watched as everything and everyone I knew died in front of my eyes. It was horrible.I somehow managed to survive that horrid day, I found the survivors and rebuilt our civilisation. We discovered many things that would aid us in our lives. We grew stronger and conquered our enemies.We discovered a large metal cylinder inside one of our opponents buildings that were not nothing but dust. The cylinder opened, and I remembered. I remembered the day that my friends died. It was that flying monster, that horrible, horrible thing that killed us all. But I had to explore it.Night was falling, and we had defeated every living thing that could possibly be a threat. No mercy. Just death. A thick fog blinded us as we made our way back to the spaceship. It towered above us yet again. The rest of my fellow friends stood beside me, and crowded around the ship. I opened the hatch and walked inside. I felt the eyes of many people watch closely as I disappeared into the darkness of the spaceship.A whole new world surrounded me. It was amazing. I flew further out of the planets gravitational pull. Out of the solar system. I gazed over the white pretty lights sparkling and twinkling in front of me.Then I saw it. Another person to defeat.The enemy spaceship wizzed around me as I tried to find a way to fight back. BOOM! A missile hit the ship. The spaceship fell off course, and was aiming straight back to my planet. Those red lights punctured the ship and cut it in half.I flailed helplessly as I was pulled out of the spaceship, still falling back to the planet. I realised that I was about to die. Tears fell down my cheeks as I choked without the oxygen I needed to live. I hoped I would pass out before I hit the surface of our barren planet that was ripped of resources by us.I waited for my death. Closer and closer the planet came. Helplessly falling. Down and down. I remembered everyone I loved and knew, and felt sorry. I should of fought with them against the spaceship. Instead of being a coward and running. I should of fought, and not care if I died. At least I would go down as a hero.Another single tear fell down my left cheek, and I hit the ground.10/10, I really enjoy exploring new planets and species. I love the first stage, it's like agar.io!

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
 WAIT FOR A SALE!  I've played like 77 hours of this game, I launch it through the dlc Galctic Adventures so all my hours are on that. Not that hours make a review more reliable, but they help show that I do know what's going on with this game. It's kind of a nastalgia game for me too becuase I played it first in the demo when I was a kid, all you could do then is make a creature. I've been playing the game every now and then for around 9 years. I have it on Origin too for some reason Idk I just really like this game. Spore is a weird creation, survival, & strategy game. You can create a creature and just leave it alone, or you can play as it through various time periods. (Cell, tribal, space age, etc). Alternatively you can have creatures you've created encounter you throughout your journey while playing as a diffferent creature. I can't get the online to work anymore, it just consists of sharing content you've made and downloading other's. The cute dlc sucks, just get the space one if any. It's not very good either but it's better than the cute one. The space dlc let's you make your own stories and adventures, which is fun. The game's adventure is super cool until you reach the tribal stage then it's like "Yea, ok. So this like an optional viewmode, right?"  NOPE!  After the creature stage, the game shifts you into this weird, strategy game with your clan of tribecreatures are fighting (or co-oporating) with other tribes. The game remains like that for the rest of it. Weird strategy that is frankly really boring. I just like making creatures and making my own adventures, even though I can't share them because the online won't work. Yea, it's not the best game, but it's fun for a bit and you should buy it IF it's on sale.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												Spore has always been a fantastic game for me, my brother, sister, even our friends to create wacky creatures and enjoy the content at which Spore provided, I don't know anyone who dislikes this game! I will admit, once you get to the space stage there's nothing much going on other than the infamous ("Grox") or whatever.. Here are some of our thoughts on how Spore could have been improved overall as a game:* Bigger planets and better customization of nests, villages, towns, etc.* Weather effects on the planet, if you're in a snowy plains your creature could potentially freeze to death if it hasn't evolved to such a degree making life on your planet a treacherously hazardous one indeed!* A lot more customizability, it's one of the biggest things keeping Spore alive to date and we all agree we wish there was more to the whole customization of it all so we could create our amazing potential top of the food chain ruler of the Galaxy.* More to the whole space stage, you work so hard to get to it and you're not even a quater of the way finished.. the space stage is so long, tedious, and perpetual a lot more customizability and content could really go into improving it. Perhaps something like orbital space cannons that defend the planet you place them around; having alien ships drop off tanks and troops to overall make the invading of another planet more interesting; the mining of planets and stars for steady cash flow to fund your endeavors in this empire of yours and beyond! Having to do all the work to make money while also defending and invading planets over time especially with as many as you encounter and in the distance you encounter them in simply put becomes ludicrous insanly fast.. like come on, defend yourselves for once! The player shouldn't always be required to save a planet from some kind of mythical disaste only they can stop apparently.* The ability to forge numbers in your army to send armies of troops to invade/defend planets for you without you having to even leave the star system you're currently in.* Have freight shipments go to and collect your resources for you automatically based on the number of freight ships you have available.Well those were some of the ideas we discussed.. overall, game's worth a play in my opinion and was a fantastic game for its generation. ;)

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												I have to say, When Spore first came out, I hated it. The original concept for the game was one of breathtaking scope and potential. After the developers got EA involved, things seemed to take a turn for the worse. By the time the game was actually released - it was not what I, and I suppose many others, had hoped it would be. Spore as it exists today is a vastly simplified version of what it could have been and did not live up to it's potential. A fact so lamentable that after just a few hours on it,  I didn't play it again for 5 years. I have recently decided to give it another chance, and time must be a great healer because I am now able to see past the failed potential, to the see the real game that Spore is. Yes, it makes a complete mockery of evolutionary history when you go from a cell (which somehow has eyes and bones) to a creature with legs, but despite this cartoonish simplification you can still have a lot of fun with spore.The creature creator is excellent; powerful and easy-to-use (when you get familiar with it), it allows you to create almost anything you can imagine. Whether it's you and some friends getting together to make some funny creatures or seriously trying to create a master race - it's going to be fun. The procedural animation generation is brilliant too, and despite our best efforts to 'break' it; my friends and I consistently found our creatures being able to move and walk well enough to play the game with.Spore tries, fairly successfully, to be 5 games in one. Pac-man, WoW, Populous, Command and Conquer and A 4X game such as Galactic Civs. The problem, of course, is that you will have played better versions of each genré that Spore offers.  The transition between these genrés is jarring too. Rather than seamlessly blending gameplay styles as you slowly gain or loose abilities from generation to generation, the game instead lurches you violently and abruptly from one game style to the next. There are other continuity errors, highlighted at the end of each stage when it displays the time-line of your creation. Despite only getting the chance for a few generations in each stage, it confidently informs you that 3 or 4 billion years is somehow supposed to have passed. You can also radically alter your creature every time you breed, which contradicts the concept of fostering a single species through it's evolution.The cell and creature stages are definately the most fun to play - but, unfortunately, you will feel rushed through. Even on 'hard' mode,  the stages are very short unless you purposefully drag them out, and the game seems determined to get you on to the final frontier, the space stage. While this is all well and good - the space stage itself is pretty boring - consisting of performing the same, basic routine missions and activities over and over again in order to expand your empire. At this point, your creation looses all sense of individuality and because of this the space stage seems somewhat lacking and definately not worth the seeming rush to get there.If you have an active imagination, and an interest in seeing what others can come up with, Spore can be very fun indeed. Especially if you can get online (I cannot as I bought the product through steam and EA claim I don't own the game) the space stage can be great as you get to explore other peoples' creations and ecosystems, painted planets etc.It seems though, that my original qualm with spore is the reason why I got bored of it again - the depth and scope of the core concept far outweighs the actual end result, and while I can finally appreciate Spore for what it is, I cannot help but be dissapointed when I think about what it could have been.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Incredibly addicting. Takes you through the evolution of any creature you wish, making it your own and then thrusting it into the world to interact and thrive based on the traits you gave it. Think of it as a mix between the customization of Sims, the city-building of Sid Meyer's Civ (starting at the base level of a microbe), and the all-powerful freedom of Godus. Got it on the Steam sale, greatest (discounted) purchase I have made yet.

It is a sandbox game not a realistic game, it is to express creativity among players not false images of evolution. That is why if they say, type or write something idiotic about Spore, in fact about any game ignore them and buy it or promote it. It is your choice not the media's.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												I going to be very direct and honest here. Simply put, God gave the gifts of imagination and creativity to all Mankind. These happen to be two of my favorite gifts that God gave us. Spore happens to be a game that allows for alot of creativity and imagination on the part of the player!!! That in itself makes the game awesome!!! There are an incredible amount of options for creating your own race of creatures and the creativity does not stop there. You can design all your buildings as well as all your vehicles (land vehicles, boats, flying machines such as helicopters, airplanes, spaceships and any other flying devices you can think of.), you can decide which plants and animals will be placed on which planet for them to inhabit. You can also terraform any planet in pratically everyway!!! You can raise or lower the land, change the atmosphere and even change the color of the sky of each planet!!! Now I could go on forever about the creativity of the game, but I really need to mention that the play control is excellent and more importantly the gameplay is truly excellent!!! I'll finish by saying that Spore is not only my favorite game of all time, but I also believe that Spore is currently THE BEST GAME OF ALL TIME!!!

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												Alright, you know what people? I'm sick of seeing 'this is better than NMS' all over the place. First of all, spore is NOT any less buggy and incomplete. I love spore, but by Spode, if I have to look at how it's soooo much better than No Man's Sky too much more, I might barf. No Man's Sky, from what I saw, is a phenominal shot at something that just needed more work, which could also be said about spore. You know what the difference is? Spore was made by EA, (An actually well known company that freaking knows better) but they never implemented autosave, have ZERO support, can't get their servers to work for♥♥♥♥♥♥ is notoriously horrible for using key codes all over the place in the most obnoxious ways, and has a budget that would make trump mildly impressed. No Man's Sky is an indie game... a very good indie game... that just needed more time before release, and for some reason, it's become a 'meme' for horrible game design and space-genre failure, which I just don't think it deserves. But by all means, keep bashing on it, because if I was the game developer, there is NO reason I can think of to properly finish the game and make something incredible once half the world thinks it's the standard for horrible.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Despite being released in 2008, this game still rivals even new releases. I've been a huge fan of Spore since I first played it in 2010, and am still dumbfounded by the level of creativity of some of the community's creations.Some people seem to be having issues with their Steam Key not being verified correctly when signing up for online. I too had this problem. Thankfully I had my old account to fall back on, but I do reccomend that you look into this issue before purchasing the game. The community aspect of this game is what really makes it shine, and the game suffers somewhat without it.This game has serious replayability, and the exploration aspect is mindblowing. You can explore an entire galaxy full of stars, the vast majority of which have orbiting planets, some of which have moons. Alongside this, the space stage has a number of beautiful features such as binary systems, black holes, protoplanetary systems, a stunning galactic core, cube planets, and the elusive storybook planets. There are also many others including easter eggs (finding Earth, for example).Each stage is as good as the previous, and the level of customisation is mindblowing. For this price, everyone should be buying this game... Well, I'd be saying that if online worked for everyone.

content:
Posted: February 14
												This game is Great. People call it Glitchy or Bad but I don't think that. The game let's you Make your Own Creature and Share with the World. The Game has 2 DLC Packs which just Add's on to the already Fun and Great Gameplay. Sure some people say it could of been better with the Feature's that the Beta Had like Bloody Battle's, Aquatic Stage and More but I think the game is still Great. Sure I Do wish the Beta Build does get Released and Trust me there is people trying to do that with Change.org and Stuff like that but there is Mods for that. Which Bring's me to my Next Point... THE COMMUNITY. The game has a HUGE Community who really Like this Game as Much As I do. Over the Years the Game has Seen Thousands OF Mods like Dark Injection's. content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												For an 8 year old game, I think Spore has held up very well against the times. Despite its age this game has managed to retain a uniquely fun and engaging charm that and plays out in a way that makes it feel very unique for such a seemingly simple game.One of the thing that helps Spore stand out in my mind would be the way the game shuffles itself around with each stage you progress through. In the Cell Stage, your in a 2D enviroment. Creature Stage your in a third person 3D enviroment. For the Tribal Stage & Civilisation Stage, the game takes on more of an RTS-esque feel, and the Space Stage it becomes a third-person space ship flying like game.Not only that, but the game hasvarious different unique playstyles that can suit practically anyone, and depending on the path the player picks, it can have huge and very interesting effects on their game down the line depending on how you like to play, with things such as traits playing a huge part in the game as your progress.Needless to say, Spore has a seemingly endless amount of content, and there's almost certainly something for everyone. No two game ways can ever be truly the same as far as Im concerned, and this game is undoubtebly a must have for any and everyone. To summarise, things, the games tagline of "From Single Cell to Galactic God" is arguably one of the best one-line descriptions a game can get and couldn't be more accurate.

												(6.5/10) [65%]The Universe is HUGE.You build.evolve Your alien race in the first 35% of the game. The only use for all your hard work in the first part, is to have Your aliens and designs look a certain way, and unlocking the next part of the game. The rest of the game is pretty much diplomacy, terraforming and trading.The game does not have enough depth, for a space type sim. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												The game itself is pretty straight-forward. Creating your own species is fun, finding parts to change your species (and its stats) feels fun and rewarding in its own way, and watching your species grow from single-celled organisms to walking/thinking/breathing land creatures is awesome.There are a few issues. Namely creature mobility in certain stages, and weird glitches in customization. I bought this for $5 and frankly, I would've easily paid a little more.The problem is there is no online multiplayer anymore, meaning some of the advertised features no longer work. All of the multplayer/online features involved finding player-created creatures/houses/buildings in your game. That's about it. Even with no multiplayer, the game is still fun.The last problem I have with the game is it's pretty short. Completionists can easily clear a majority of the game in under 10 hours. All in all, fun game, would recommend.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												What I learned from Spore:1. Killing someone without any weapons is less impressivle when you have a set of arms with saws for hands.2. Even when you have even wider tracts of land, people still like it when you tell them you admire theirs.3. When in doubt, give them fish and all is forgiven.4. Music unites all.My experience with spore:>Had my eye on it for more then 1 month>Mom buys it for 20 dollars but something happens and the file can't run>Slowly forget about it's existance>Years pass>Sees JackSepticEye play it>All the memories flood back>One year passes in which i keep my eye on this game wait for the perfect opprotunity>That opprotunity comes when I see it's on sale for five dollars>Insantly buy it with no regrets.>The game is amazing, just like i knew it would be>Play the sh*t out of it for 2 days straight in which I kill EVERYONE>Start a new game on the third day>Becomes  the next hitler  Donald Trump and buys everything>To be continuedOn the real though, this game is a steal, even at it's normal price of 5 dollars. Did I love it? Hell yes I did. Do I miss the servers? Hell yes I do. BUT, maxis did such an amazing job with creature diversity that I honestly can still play the game with the creatures they made, and the "Deja vu" Creatures I made earlier. Would I reccommend it? HELL TO THE YES.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Despite being released in 2008, this game still rivals even new releases. I've been a huge fan of Spore since I first played it in 2010, and am still dumbfounded by the level of creativity of some of the community's creations.Some people seem to be having issues with their Steam Key not being verified correctly when signing up for online. I too had this problem. Thankfully I had my old account to fall back on, but I do reccomend that you look into this issue before purchasing the game. The community aspect of this game is what really makes it shine, and the game suffers somewhat without it.This game has serious replayability, and the exploration aspect is mindblowing. You can explore an entire galaxy full of stars, the vast majority of which have orbiting planets, some of which have moons. Alongside this, the space stage has a number of beautiful features such as binary systems, black holes, protoplanetary systems, a stunning galactic core, cube planets, and the elusive storybook planets. There are also many others including easter eggs (finding Earth, for example).Each stage is as good as the previous, and the level of customisation is mindblowing. For this price, everyone should be buying this game... Well, I'd be saying that if online worked for everyone.

												What I learned from Spore:1. Killing someone without any weapons is less impressivle when you have a set of arms with saws for hands.2. Even when you have even wider tracts of land, people still like it when you tell them you admire theirs.3. When in doubt, give them fish and all is forgiven.4. Music unites all.My experience with spore:>Had my eye on it for more then 1 month>Mom buys it for 20 dollars but something happens and the file can't run>Slowly forget about it's existance>Years pass>Sees JackSepticEye play it>All the memories flood back>One year passes in which i keep my eye on this game wait for the perfect opprotunity>That opprotunity comes when I see it's on sale for five dollars>Insantly buy it with no regrets.>The game is amazing, just like i knew it would be>Play the sh*t out of it for 2 days straight in which I kill EVERYONE>Start a new game on the third day>Becomes  the next hitler  Donald Trump and buys everything>To be continuedOn the real though, this game is a steal, even at it's normal price of 5 dollars. Did I love it? Hell yes I did. Do I miss the servers? Hell yes I do. BUT, maxis did such an amazing job with creature diversity that I honestly can still play the game with the creatures they made, and the "Deja vu" Creatures I made earlier. Would I reccommend it? HELL TO THE YES.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
"Greater than the sum of its parts"Spore is less of a "simulation game" and more of an "adventure through evolution". The vision of Will Wright's epic "Universe Simulator" didn't turn out quite as many sims fans might expect. Now hold on, while I do not think Spore met its very high expectations set back circa E3 2005's demo, I did enjoy and love Spore.Spore is one part creation tool, one part action/adventure game and one part RTS game. The game is split into five stages, cell, creature, tribal, civilisation and space. The cell and creature stages play like a simple action RPG game, eating plants or killing/socialising with other creatures to raise your  "level" and unlock new parts as you evolve. Eventually your creature gains greater intelligence and moves to the tribal stage and civ stage where they play out like very simple RTS games and the Space stage return to a more action RPG format with some diplomacy sprinkled in. Each of these five stages are very simple, in fact they feel like far simpler versions of other games in the same genre. One could equate the cell stage as a very simplistic version of pacman, except with the lack of mazes. Your goal is simple: eat, grow big, and avoid ghosts - well in this case, predators, unless of course if you play a carnivore where your mission is to instead others. As a creature, the game shifts to a third person action RPG style game, depending on how your creature evolves, you gain different attacks and abilities to use as you fight of predators, socialise, or hunt down prey. At the tribal and civ stage, the games are very simple versions of Battle For Middle Earth. If you never played that very awesome Lord of the Rings based RTS game by EALA, you should definitely check it out. Ultimately though, each of these stages feel very bland and personally, lacks variety. While you creature creator allows you to make a variety of different creatures, the ability variety and units/building variety at civ stages are just too few. There's very little option for different strategies in any of these four stages. What makes up for it for me, is two things - the creature creator and the space stage. The creature creator is one of the best selling points of spore - who doesn't like to see your favourite fantasy creatures move and come to life? It is also nice to look at the timeline which your creature evolved, to see how they started from a single worm like cell with a glowing electric butt to a ferocious dragon thing wearing a top hat and sporting a beard (at least that's how my creature turned out) lel. The Space stage is perhaps the most fleshed out, and most satisfying stage to play in Spore. It is clearly the stage that Maxis put most time into. While there is no longer any evolution taking place, what makes the space stage so great is the blend of diplomacy, where you have to ally or fight off neigbouring alien empires, look for resources, spread your empire, abduct creatures from lesser civilisations for study or alternatively, lift them up to the space stage, terraform planets, or just drop a planet buster and blow them to bits. Space stage is most satisfying due to the greater level of difficulty, the things you have to manage and the variety of things to do. The first time you drop the atmosphere machine to pump a desolate planet full of air before throwing a down a blizzard machine to cool it down to the right temperature is so satisfying. What's  even more satisfying is deterraforming a planet - i.e. finding an alien empire and messing up their ecosystem and cause them to go extinct, I mean Why not!? Ha! (Goddam Zealots and their ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Spode....)Individually, each stage of Spore is quite weak, but put together, Spore is definitely a very good game. And since most stage won't take you more than an hour to beat anyway, the lack of variety of the first four stages won't get too much in the way and you won't be bored by it because once you're done, you are doing something different in the next stage. I also recommend that if you get Spore, get it with Galactic Adventures because it introduces the adventure creator which is great fun and adds more variety to the missions you get to do at Space stage while simulataneously allowing you to land on certain planets to do missions controlling your character like during the creature stage.But, however I have only one final criticism, and this is aimed squarely at EA. Although I absolutely love Spore and want to give it greater praise, at the end of the day, I feel Spore is just very very poorly supported. The online search is absolutely atrocious. The in-game Sporepedia (which is a library of creatures and creations that users can upload) takes forever to load, there's frequent disconnections and for Galactic Adventures only, the points and ranking system for new adventures are completely and utterly broken. This is sad because Spore DOES have an active, albeit small, community who still creates great creatures and adventures.The verdict? Spore is a great game as a whole package where each stage works in unison to give a fun experience. As I said, the game doesn't take too long to move through each stage and seeing how your creature evolved over time is a satisfying experience. Ultimately however, had the game have better online functionality, like say Steamworkshop integration directly with Sporepedia, I would give this game a solid 8. Criticism of each stage being too simple aside, I did enjoy my hundreds of hours on this game creating things, and messing up and blowing up planets in space stage, finding secret space objects and flying through wormholes. It just made my inner science nerd fangasm as I live my sci-fi dreams. I just adore this game. However the poor online and very old community makes it very hard for me to reccommend today and ultimately I must drop a point and give this game a 7.tl;dr should you buy this game? Only at a sale and if you are okay with EA's terrible (or actually, completely nonexistent) support for this game. I'm still recommending it, but just barely and ONLY if you are okay with the nonexistent support from EA.

												I've heard Spore was EA's last good game.They were right. The only bugs in this game are entertaining little physics glitches. Nothing too bad. That's just my first creature and I'm gonna do a full playthrough with it. It's great!...but if any of you guys want, to... you know, mess around... you can make a creature that'll fart out it's mouth. I'd give it 10/10 except it doesn't have key-bind changing options.9/10

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												The game itself is pretty straight-forward. Creating your own species is fun, finding parts to change your species (and its stats) feels fun and rewarding in its own way, and watching your species grow from single-celled organisms to walking/thinking/breathing land creatures is awesome.There are a few issues. Namely creature mobility in certain stages, and weird glitches in customization. I bought this for $5 and frankly, I would've easily paid a little more.The problem is there is no online multiplayer anymore, meaning some of the advertised features no longer work. All of the multplayer/online features involved finding player-created creatures/houses/buildings in your game. That's about it. Even with no multiplayer, the game is still fun.The last problem I have with the game is it's pretty short. Completionists can easily clear a majority of the game in under 10 hours. All in all, fun game, would recommend.

												(6.5/10) [65%]The Universe is HUGE.You build.evolve Your alien race in the first 35% of the game. The only use for all your hard work in the first part, is to have Your aliens and designs look a certain way, and unlocking the next part of the game. The rest of the game is pretty much diplomacy, terraforming and trading.The game does not have enough depth, for a space type sim.  You have to get to the center of the universe,  fighting off "cyborg gremlins".The game is worth-while playing, and fun. Sets the stage for cerebral expansion, and future thoughts.

												-Go in-Create a weird thing-Die 100 times-Have E10+ sex-Make the weirdest thing possible-Team with a species-Murder a species-Either murder or team with every single species in the game-Realizes that you still need more DNA to level up-Walk 100,000,000 miles away from home-Find some epic bones-Get killed by a mega-creature-Realize you can add creautres to your pack-Add creatures to your pack-Get in a huge fight-Run away as you watch your pack get murdered-Die-Look for tons of bones-Finally go to Tribal stage-Farm food for an hour-Attack an opposing tribe-Win just barely-Feel good about yourself-Get attacked by a different tribe on your way home-Lose-Restart tribal stage-Try to team with everyone-Succeed-Go into civilization stage-Find your first spice geyser-Farm it-Another city takes your spice geyser-Try to take over that city-Suceed-Feel good about self-Take over all other cities-Realize that the game is getting repetitive-Get bored and use the final powerup to go into the space stage-Create a weird ship that shouldn't be able to fly-Play for a bit more-Get angry at the tutorial-Not do any tutorial missions-Realize you have to do the tutorial missions to advance-Never play the game again-5 months later get bored and start over10/10 would waste my life again

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												Program reputation for reliability - 6Fun - 9 Replay - 9 (I think the games gameplay-variety is responsible for such high replayability, but just low-effort guess)Depth - 8 (with lots of collecting, achievements, items, and parts thrown ontop of an already lengthy game, lots to do)Graphics - 7 (given the style, it hasn't aged poorly and is still easy on the eyes)Audio - 7 (quite good! and often pretty cute/disturbing as well)UI Ease - 6 (Some game mechanics are a little uncooperative and once identified, have to be in turn used against the AI. space combat comes to mind as does land-creature movement and tribal group and order management)DLC- I can't speak for the DLC. Unfortunately, "signs point to no"Spore tends to get some mixed reviews, but between the yea and nae side, I'm definitely with the "yea"s.Despite some rather nasty bugs I've seen reported (yet have never experienced myself across 3 different PC builds with 3 different versions of windows of the games era) and a few un-fulfilled promises about the amount and variety of gameplay Spore would have, it's still a wonderful game and fits into my collection quite nicely between SimLife, Civilization, and EscapeVelocity. I'm kinda dating myself a little with those references, but if you enjoyed those games or the genres they came from, then collectively you'll likely enjoy SporeYou start in a cellular / molecular stage which is...well...Sparkle2Evo..."thats all I got to say 'bout that."Next, you're on land and as a walking, talking, biting creature have more of a "squad leader & servants" role to play in eating, killing, mating, and exploring your way through new body parts that offer bigger and better bonuses to gameplay.Then you move to a rudimentary Age of Empires tribal stage where you manage a small flock of your spawn and interract with (and ultimately ravage if ya play like me and always go the hostile route over the cuddly, fuzzy, social route which IS offered I might mention) other tribes of creatures.Then you hit the global "Civilization" stage where you're moving ground, air, and sea units to claim, control, and harvest resources while you devise the downfall or annexing of your neighboring nations.And last but certainly far from least, the space stage. This part of the game could have (and in the past, regularly was, and with great success; see EV:Nova) been its own full-production game. Exploring space, planet-scaping newly discovered worlds for colonization, a (rather awkward and sometimes uncooperative) combat system with various upgrades and features all coat this area of the game with a thick layer of nerdy OCD. Here you meet other species, conduct trade routes, colonize planets, establish automated trade routes, improve your ship, explore further and further and with more and more efficiency and profit making more and more homeworlds as you go for your species until...well....honestly I haven't gotten past this part. I enjoy it too much and haven't wanted it to end any of the half a dozen or so times I've played to this point and coasted along in place for a while before setting it down only to start over again later to replay it all.There have been many frustrations with this game for me, partly because I enjoyed it so much I didn't want anything to go wrong ever, most often it was due to a program crash that would hit me unexpectedly when I hadn't saved my game in a particularly productive couple of hours. But it was easily more a problem with my computers than it was the software itself.But that being said...I know the integrity of the program has been in question multiple times so...for some notable ratings...actually I suppose I'll put them at the top.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												I'd say Spore is just about good, because of its detailed creature/building/vehicle creation. The first four stages are fun to play, but the space stage gets extremely boring very quickly - it is mostly just about going around dumping colony packs everwhere you go, and then going back to your planets to collect "spice". Its worth playing if you like games with plenty of user created content, but those looking for an exiting strategy game should go to civilization or something of the like. The space stage does get significantly better with the Galactic Adventures dlc, though not really enough to make it fun. The game also has good mod-ability, but modding can damage your ability to use the online aspects of the game.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												Spore is a unique game. It lets you create your own species and evolve them from microscopic cells, to a space-fairing empire. As you go along each stage, you get to use a powerful editor that lets you create virtualy anything you want. You could create something out of Mass Effect or Halo, or whatever you want. Imagination is the limit! When not in the editors, you will be spending time in Spore's 5 different stages. Each stage has its own kind of gameplay, giving you different genres of playstyle. I enjoyed all of the stages, but thre were a few problems I had. The lack of an auto save feature can be annoying at times. The gme sometimes crashes and  when I forget to save, I lose alot or all progress. (So remember to save) Another problem I had was in tribal stage were my tribe's men wouldn't harvest meat from hunting. (This wasn't too big a deal, I just restarted the game and it was fixed) There are a few bugs here and there, but they shouldn't be gamebreaking. Overall, this is one of my favorite games. (If you like this game, be sure to heck out it's other awesome dlcs.)

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												I cannot recommend this game in it's current state. It will freeze up and crash on me every 30 to 90 minutes. I've done the end of the creature stage 4 times now and the beginning of the tribal stage 2 to 3 times. I've finally realized that I need to just save it every 10 minutes, but it is very frustrating.For the actual gameplay, it is an incredible game. The process and method used to develop your species is absolutely phenonmenal and I am loving it thus far. I cannot wait to get to the end of the tribal stage and grow into an almighty civilization. I have no doubt it will be a lot of fun when I get there, but I hate the fact that this game freezes and crashes so often with no error message or anything of the nature.I want to recommend this game so badly as it is built so well, but the crashes are too huge a turn off for me.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
Product received for free
												Spore is a fun little game, very similar to Sims (Both developed by Maxis). Although there are a lot of bugs (See what I did there?), the game is still enjoyable and most issues are easily resolved. The graphics aren't too bad and each evolutionary stage offers a different type of gameplay, each are enjoyable, though some more than others. The first stage is somewhat like the popular app Agar.io, then, what lured me into the game was the creature stage; creating your very own monster. Then a little bit of strategy and finally you get to travel into space and discover planets etc.Whilst the game looks like it was designed to appeal to children (probably was) I'm sure anyone can get some enjoyment from it.7.5/10

content:
Posted: March 26
												The Good: You might enjoy this game if you're really into the idea of customizing and tweaking your creature. Or if you're just looking for a very casual game to enjoy without much of a learning curve.The Bad: What I wanted out of spore though was the feeling of starting from a single celled organism and eventually taking over the entire planet and/or galaxy. And while spore attempts to do this, it doesn't feel epic in any way. It just feels like a series of very simplistic minigames. It didn't feel very rewarding to win.On top of that the mechanics didn't feel very crisp. Even after 13 hours of play I still didn't feel like I grasped the mechanics very well.

												The novelty of being able to create your own creatures is amazing and fun for a while. However, since EA shut down it's servers for the game and it has no mod support, it simply isn't worth buying as it gets stale very quickly. The game tries to be too many games at once, and doesn't go past surface level on any of its different "phases". Honestly it's only fun with some friends so you can mess around and make extremely ugly creatures. Which means past the creature stage it loses all charm and becomes a forgetable "4x", if it even counts as that. Don't buy unless you have nothing else worth buying and it's on sale.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												The game is divided into 5 stages, and each stage features a somewhat different style of gameplay. Most are like real-time strategy, but they are different and diverse. So it's basically 5 games in one pack. Not only that, the whole game is about your very own creature evolving from one single cell to the biggest race that controls the whole universe. It feels EPIC. It feels like you are the god.The space stage, being the last stage, is immense with content, and endless. Everyone talks about this epic journey into the heart of galaxy, because it's fantastic. It can get very hard, with the Grox attacking you in laaaarge numbers. You have to tear out a way the hard way, planet by planet, among heavily occupied star systems. But when you do reach the center, you get this feeling again that after billions of years of evolving and fighting and growing you finally become the emperor of the universe. It is moving, trust me. And aside from this main quest (it may not even be main - the game doesn't require you to do this), there are tons of things to do. You can collect artifacts from around the galaxy, ally or fight with other equally advanced races, work toward various badges and unlock the very best equipment, play the financial way by trading spices, and so much more.At the end of each stage, you get an ability based on your behavior in this stage to help you with the next stage. If you are violent you get an ability that attacks. If you are social you get an ability that helps making friends. And if you play from the very first cell stage all the way to space, you get an ultimate ability for the space stage. There are a good number of different abilities you can get this way, and they create a good number of various playstyles. Conclusion, what you do as a cell at day 1 will affect what you do outside of your home planet.And of course there's this famed creature creator. You can create EVERYTHING with it. And not only creatures, but also houses, factories, turrets, vehicles, ships, planes, spaceships, and more. WIth Internet connection you can share your creations with other players. In fact these guys at EA are so proud of this creator that they make it one option at the main menu. Yes you can go to the creator and start creating without launching the main game at all.So is there any complaint at all? Well there is. At whatever stage, if you make a lot of allies, you will be annoyed at how they keep attacking one another and seeking help from you all the time. Makes me think back to Civilization. Can't they just learn to live in peace, like me?! And when I first installed the game it says my key wasn't valid. But just contact EA and they can solve this quickly.All in all, this game is marvelous, and is recommended for everyone.Edit: well seems like online action has been dead for some time. Sorry for the inaccuracy. And here I thought there's this magical guy named Maxis who created a lot and lot and lot of things. Other than that this game still rocks.+ epic adventure+ variety of playstyle+ creativity- first 4 stages are too short10 out of 10, masterpiece.
