content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												Please, if you're reading this, GET THIS GAME. This is one of the brightest, best, most ingenius games of all time. I don't know what you're thinking it looks like, but once you play it through, you'll know why many call this a "Masterpiece".Don't be fooled by my hours. I played this long just to write a review. I have had this game since it's release in 2007/2008 and along with that used the expansion pack Galactic Adventures.Sometime in this world, this game will climb from the grave of olden forgotten games and rise above all in a blinding light. It will look down upon the next generation of gamers and wave its finger. It will bathe them all in its healing glow, and the unfathomable legend that is Spore will ask them; "How will you create the universe?"With that out of the way, let's get to some points.GOOD:- Open the game. Look at the title screen. Put your hands around the screen as devilish or heroic you want. YOU HAVE AN ENTIRE GALAXY TO COMPLETELY CHANGE TO YOUR VERY OWN WILL.- I recommend this game.- You can change anything. Literally. Serious here. Except plants. Sky? Water? Land formations? Vehicles? Your face? A city and it's entire layout? How about the song that plays in cities 24/7 and tortures it's civilians? Make it as monotonous as you wish. Oh, you can also change other planets. Don't have to be yours.- Funny. Oh, no I don't mean the game's humor. No, I don't mean giant walking pink floppy things. I mean: you have to get used to this game and know how it works. When something goes wrong or stupid, you'll know. xD- I recommend this game.- Plenty of glitches to exploit the creators to make some pretty cool looking stuff.- Classic RPG feel but without an annoying "Level"ing system.- If the community was active, it has a very flexible way to find other people's stuff and do things with it. ^^- GET THIS GAME ALREADY.- Play this game. Make stuff. Make it evolve. Click the timeline button. CRY LIKE YOU'VE NEVER DONE BEFORE.I feel like I'm betraying 9 years of my life and my favorite game of all time by writing this, but...BAD:- The community is D.E.A.D. Which is why we need to CHANGE THAT.- No multiplayer. Boo. :<However, along with no multiplayer, you can still access, comment, message, all that good stuff to people you're friends with in the game. Put their creations in your own little world and DESTROY THEM!Somewhere out there, there are still people making stuff. Well. Besides me.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												I liked this game for many reasson, it has unlimited replayability with every experience being new. To me that is vital in a game. While it may say I only have 27 hours I have well over a 500 or so as I got it when I was just a kid and played on CD for many years. Enough about me though, we are talking about the game. This game has had many issues with it along with many pros. When it was first released there was much back lash on the scientific problems with the game. Such as how the comets tails face the wrong way and a lot of people felt as if they were cheated. From what I understand this was advertised as The Sims only in a global way. custimization and such was supposed to be through the roof while it may apeearr not true I find it to be as close to that as it can be. For the technology that was available when the game was produced.       The game was far ahead of its time and if remade with modern technology it would take the world by storm. I would not be suprised if No Mans Sky got ideas from this game. Finding houndreds of creatures that the creators have made and back when multiplayer was still supported you could find an endless amount from simple to very complex creatures, maybe even considered artistic. I can still remember one I found named boot wjich indeed looked like a boot to every detail. That is the thing about the game. You can slap on the best parts and have a beast machine but you will most likely not like it asthetically.      The Pros:               Replayability, cheap, imaginative      The Cons:               Cartoonish, and space age. The Cons (explained)    While the cartoony graphics may push off more mature players my younger self did not care. They can be a bit hard to get use to and may drive some off but maybe not. My big issue is the Space age stage. While everyone is different I find it to be the worst part about the game and it makes up well over 70% of a play through if not more. The space is is grindy and very very long. It makes up for it by having a lot to do I find it to be to drug out. You can only buy planets at such a rate and travel so far with out going to war for resources or to level up. For instance on the 27 hours I have on here roughly 20 or more were in the space age and I have got alomost nowhere. That may be me though I know people who hate it and people who love it.Anyway I would rate the game a solid 8/10 because if you do not like the space age you can always restart.

												Yes, this game was a disapointment during development and had an amazing amount of potential, but this should not be a factor in whether THIS game is good or not. I will tell you what's good and bad about this game with as little bias possible.In short. It can be a fun early game, but expect to steadily become annoyed by gameplay.If you think it would be fun to create your own civilization of alien creatures and put detailed work into their architecture, vehicle design, and ideology(kinda); this is the game for you. If you want to rush through everything and make your tanks floating white cubes, then you're better spending your money on something else. This game is more like a toybox than a video games. It can be a lot of fun only if you have an active imagination.Personally, vehicle creation is what I've had the most fun with. You can make some amazing stuff if you put some work into it. I've seen a creation someone made of the Pelican from HALO and it looks freaking awesome. Or you could make a flying d*** plane like most people seem to make.Now the downside:The stages from cell->creature->tribe->civilization->space are incredibly rushed. You can get by cell stage in 10 minutes and the creature, tribe, and civilization stages might take you an hour each if you're taking your sweet time. From this it seems like the developers thought that the space stage should consist of the majority of your gameplay. I loved the civilization stage, but it sucks so much how much that it's rushed. If you've been sitting around enough with a fair amount of cities, other civilization will even go "**** it. I'm gonna give you all my cities" as if they're rage quiting. There is literally no strategy to warfare at all. All that matters is who has the most units. Other civilizations aren't even that violent either. They just sit there all game waiting for you to either throw bibles, bullets, or money at them (keep in mind, this is NORMAL difficulty). Space:Now the biggest problem with space age is that there is literally no automization whatsoever. Your planet could be covered in turrets and have a uber turret and if a pirate or whatever attacks the planet and you're not there to overlook it, the planet will either suffer lots of damage or be lost. I just want to adventure from star to star and my star citizens will scream at me to stop biodisasters or kill pirates every 2 minutes. Other nations can send entire fleets of ships to take over your planet, but whenever you want to take over one, you have to do it aaaalll by yourself (and a few allied ships if you have them).To developers:Is it so hard to program automatic trading between your stars? Is it so hard to let my planets defend themselves with their own weapons? The scope of the game gets bigger and bigger as you play yet management has stayed the same as it has in cell stage.It dissapoints me that this game isn't very good. I love every idea this game has to offer, but everything is so poorly executed. If there were a remake of this game where it's made realisitc looking with in-depth stages, I would buy it in a heartbeat. Recommendation: If this game is $5, go nuts.

												Well this was the biggest 60/40 game I have ever seen. The first 3 stages of the game ( cell, creature, and tribe ) are very good and kept me playing. But the civlization is stupid thanks to camera control and contest crafting and future gets boring very fast. It does have replayability in the first 3 and I think I will come back to create different creatures very soon. But those last 2 stages are impossible to get through. Think of it like this, when I was on the first 3 stages it was 4 straight hours of fun. Got into civilization, constent pausing, to exiting, to playing a better game. I recommend purchase but only around $10.00 to make sure you get the enjoyment of the first 3 stages and see if you like the last 2.NOTE IF YOU HAVE WINDOWS: If you once at anytime click the windows button it will knock you out of the game and you will be stuck ( usually in ground ) for ever on any game level except cellular. In short save often or it's a reset.My score: 6/10 above average

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												Trying to contact support was like trying to dash towards a train while the doors were closing, if the window of oppoortunity shuts in your face, you will be finding yourself at the station waiting for the next chance to come along, especially since there have no way to actually email them. Even when I arrive at the station, I will at times glitch out and disconnect, having to log back in several times to enter.Getting in the game was a chore, but I remained optimistic to see what they would pull off by making several genres combine into a concept of evolution with large end game content. The excitement faded over time, as I realized after each stage that it was getting more shallow than the previous, the worst being the RTS stage before you reach the end game.The RTS stage being the most clearly basic and clunky form of AI this game has to offer you, beating the goals of this evolution stage are extremely easy. With one entertainment building you can maximize profit in every city with ease, while keeping your citizens happiness neutral. This made it apparent that having multiple genres and treating them like mini-games that you do for end game content, was in essence a foolish move. The customization itself is rather a shallow husk, adding several guns, rockets, and flamethrowers to a tank won't result in any increased power, its like if I was watching "The Mask" as a child again. Even in earlier stages where you can customize your spore it didn't result in any actual difference in how well it fought against the other dinosaurs. The customization ends up as a purely cosmetic concept, lucky for us they aren't charging it as DLC at least...The game still has hindering glitches after all these years was also not a good sign of their support for the game. Crashing right after dying in the creature stage for example has been around since release and still hasn't been addressed properly. Don't buy it unless you can get a massive discount.The only positive thing about this game is the humor and cutenessSo basically:- External DRM.- Extremely minimalistic and dumbeddown game, aimed at casuals.- Almost all creature and vehicle customizations (what the game is all about) are PURELY cosmetics only...- Lots of issues, bugs and connection problems.- Transition into RTS seems like an extremely bad Civilization type of game as if it was put together in a month time.- Devs ignore gamebreaking bugs like crashes entirely. They release a lot of DLC but will probably never fix it. They are too busy 'making money'.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												I contemplated for a long should I get this game since it seemed rather childish but a friend recommended it. In the end i grabbed it from the sale. I'm torn 50/50 recommending it, and not recommending. Yeah it is pretty childish and naive, yet you can have fun with it. I'm sure if I had kids they would have a blast with it.The cell stage was great, I wish it would have lasted like that with the slow evolutions way longer. I liked the swift swimming and exploring. On tribal part it gets a bit "meh", with loads of tribes annoying you until you befriend them or get rid of them, and after that even more so until you get into space age - and there I think I spent hours on hours building my empire, just to learn how vast and endless the galaxy was, staring at it both in awe and disapointment. Due some crashes and corrupted files I played to galaxy stage 3 times, each a bit different, and to my amusement kept running to my old creations quite a lot in the new worlds.After few playtimes I don't think I will ever open the game again though, and the creatures sounds and screams annoy me immensely by now. I didn't figure out how to set default buildings in galaxy so every time I take over a new planet I am forced to repick the building which is just futile. Endlessly so. And you have to do everything by "yourself" with that one little ship, making ruling over your great empire tiresome and expanding just makes it more so. There is kinda no end to it so it just wears you out in the end. I wanted to add an edit since so many are finding this review so horribly unhelpful. My playtime is  high because I kept leaving the game open when I wasn't playing, since it would so often crash and destroy my saved game when I closed it, therefore forcing me to start over repeatedly or roll back a lot. I didn't feel like giving up before reaching the end and seeing all there was to it, I guess I'm curious like that. This is however really not a hallmark of a good game, nor a sign that I "got my moneys worth in time spent", if that is what bugs you guys in this review.

												Extremely disappointed with this game, Steam and EA games.  Purchased this game and all the expansion packs which was very pricy.  The first portion of the game worked, but I could not sign up online and could not use the expansion packs at all.  I didn't know that I was not playing the expansion packs or that there was an online portion until after I reached a certain point in the game which was over the 10 hour limit by one extra hour.I contacted Steam support to let them know the issue.  They said that they no longer support EA Spore game.  Keep in mind I just purchased this a day before asking Steam for help.I then went ahead and contacted EA games.  They said in the chat window there was only a 5 minute wait.  It has been weeks and still no reply.  I called and still no answer on the phone from EA games.  Is this a joke?  I feel like I got scammed.  What is worse is that Steam is STILL selling this game.  If they don't support EA games, they should not be selling this.  Especially with all the other complaints from other players.This does not work with most recent version of Windows, but I am running this game on Windows 7 and still have issues.I will never purchase another game from Steam or EA games if this is how they treat customers.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												Wow, I bought this game thinking evolutionary decisions made will have some great impact througout the game.  It doesn't.The game really doesn't leave room for diversity.  Despite having so many choices, most of them becomes a mute issue in the next minigame (there are 5 such minigames, each one having little to do with each other).  Ultimately, you have to somehow subdue the opponents either through might or culture, but playstyle for both method is rather identical, hence the lack of actual diversified game play.  Each of the minigame weren't really polished either.  Controls are one thing; AI responses or ally reactions are poor and unrealiable.  Indeed, this game is a cohort of five mediocre games of 2008.  I've seen much better games in 1990's.Many people like it.  Well, there may be good reason for it, and for such info, go read their reviews.  As for me, after playing it through a couple times, all of which were done rather painfully hoping to be proven wrong, well, I am done trying.  I wish I could get a refund, but thankfully, I bought it on sale.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												4 out of 10Spore is not really a great game.  It is not totally horrible, "avoid at all cost", bad either.  The gameplay itself gets stale very quickly.You control a critter(s) through evolution into tribal and industrial age into the space age.  The space age is by far the best.  (I have the Galactic Adventures Pack DLC not sure what the difference is). The good:1. You can design your own critters and later on vehicles with infinite possibilities.  It did not appeal much to me though. 2. The idea is good.  The implementation not so much. The bad: 3. It is nothing like real evolution.  In the evolutionary stages you can totally change your critter's characteristics in an instant.  Evolution is small changes cumulative over many generations. 4. The game play will not keep you entertained for long.  The evolutionary lines are too similar.  Re-playability is limited. 5. Some more AI automation in the space age would have been useful.  You have to do basically everything manually.  And there is a hell of a lot of menial stuff to do. The ugly: 6. It is one of those games were doing something seemingly simple could take hours (in the space age, the other ages are not so bad). There is nothing out there I know off remotely like this.  Ultimately the gameplay is very simplistic.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												I'm not sure how validly I can review this game, given that I've never even beaten the Tribal Stage. This doesn't bother me personally so much as I think the Tribal Stage is rubbish compared to the Creature Stage, which is the concept that drew me in to begin with.The creature stage itself is plenty of fun, if a bit limited by the fact that succeeding in socialization encounters at all basically means you need to have mastery of every single form of communication, and the fact that there's no need to adapt to any particular climate or change in climate. Sure that allows for more freedom in design, but shouldn't the core concept of a game that can be summed up as "Evolution Lite" be coming up with creatures that are both awesome AND can survive the challenges the world throws at them?If you already have it, awesome, but I wouldn't recommend throwing money at this game. Better to watch and see if someone can do it better next time around.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												SPORE(tm) is a game based around creating your own creature, growing from a tiny little cell into a run-of-the-mill alien creature which roams the wildlife. When the time comes your flock of creatures will assemble a tribe, which turns into a civilization where you conquer your planet and begin to rule other planets. The concept seems solid, but if only EA and Maxis didn't royally ♥♥♥♥ this idea in the♥♥♥♥♥ My main issue with this SPORE(tm) is when each stage of the game passes, the core gameplay drastically changes.The cell stage is a top-down hold your mouse down to let your cell munch on some food and take on other cells, this isn't entirely bad as it gives you a rundown on how the game works and how to use character creation.The Creature stage is the best part of the game bar-none, you roam around a titan of a planet, populated by other player's spore creations and creatures made by Maxis. Your goal is to collect food, make friends or enemies and collect bones/fossils to help your creature evolve(Find new body parts), during this stage you'll be taking on agressive nests of creatures, rogue creatues who have mastered their ability to fight and the all-mighty epic giants which roam and demolish anything within it's path.After that, SPORE(tm) takes you into the Tribal stage, which returns you to a top-down perspective and plays like an RTS, build your village and either make peace with or destroy any other tribes on the planet.Civilization's stage of the game is the exact same as the Tribal stage, difference being you suddenly gain ludicrous technology and turn into a traitorous ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ by killing off any friends you made to rule the planet you once lived on.And finally there's space, I think you get the idea now.What EA was going for with spore didn't work at all, changing up the gameplay entirely is one of the worst things a game could do and is by far the best way to ♥♥♥♥ one up. Personally I wish they stuck with the Creature stages' sort of gameplay, moving into a tribal stage with the same perspective and having the ability to take on tougher creatures on the planet, while maintaining resources in your village, then moving on to civilisation, having even more resorces to work with and have a fair fight against creatures such as epics. Ruling the planet in that sort of way (The space stage truly wasn't necessary)Oh well, you can't get what you want all the time.I'd recommend this game if it was on sale, such as a 75% off just for the creature stage and phenominally hilarious laughs you can get out of it. Otherwise I wouldn't tell you to buy this game, even at gunpoint.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												I rate this game at about $8, and that's with the Creepy&Cute DLC (which adds nothing of value). Given that its normal price is $20 ($30 with the DLC), it would take a pretty big Steam sale to make this game worth getting.What they did is make 5 half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥mini-games, each one a different game genre, and combine them into a single game that progresses & evolves your creature through each mini-game. None of the 5 mini-games is much fun on its own. Just when one of them seems like it's about to get fun, you're done with it and have to go on to the next.The cell stage is so short and limited that it could be a Flash game. In fact, I have played many Flash games that have much more depth and enoyability than this mini-game.The creature stage is actually pretty fun the first time through, but slogging through the unlocks is not even remotely fun a second time, even if you make completely different choices.Tribal stage is a really simplistic RTS that you beat in minutes.Civilization stage is almost a 4X, except there's no "explore", "exploit", and not much of an "expand" among those 4 Xs, and diplomacy is barely a thing (though I admit I wouldn't know, as I just conquered everyone).The space stage is a more complete 4X, except you have to slowly fly your ship to any civilization/colony you want to interact with. On top of that, your one ship is the only unit you can ever really control. This portion of the game never ends - you just keep flying your ship around and doing the same boring stuff forever. The galaxy is pretty massive, which is good, but the limit to how much you can do in it, along with the tedium of flying your ship around, pretty much eliminates the appeal of the large scale.The lesson here is when you make 1/5th of 5 different games, then smush them together, you don't actually get a whole game. Sorry Maxis. The only way an idea like this could work is if each of the 5 mini-games was fleshed out and felt like a full game on its own.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												Bought this game to catch up on space colonization type games. Summary: It's a grindfest. Repetitive, simple, not fun.You "evolve" a creature through various stages. It starts out very simple as the different game types are mini games. Only the mini games become longer and longer, and their complexity stays that of mini games. There is no depth. The final space age takes this to the extreme.Example 1: Every colony you build (3 per planet), you have to drag and drop 8 turrets halfway accross the screen, then you have to set 3 factories, 1 entertainment building and about 7 houses in a simple pattern (again by drag and drop halfway across the screen). Then, if your planet is attacked, you should also check each colony individually by flying to each one in your space ship, and replace any lost buildings by drag and drop halfway accross the screen.Example 2: The enemy "AI" doesn't rebuild. To take an enemy planet, fly there, destroy some buildings, fly back to base, refuel, do some missions/alerts/trades in between (because they keep piling up), refuel again, fly to the enemy planet, destroy some more buildings, repeat until planet surrenders.Example 3: In the 4th stage, there is 1 land unit, which will be replaced with 1 air unit when air units become available.Example 4: In the 3rd stage, the only way to wipe out an enemy tribe is to wait for them to attack you, kill the attacker with your special ability, then wipe out the remaining enemies at their camp. Repeat 4 times.There are a few things that hurt the game apart from the boring gameplay:- It occasionally crashes, but  rarely enough that it's acceptable. Except that there are no autosaves. It only asks you to save on exit (unless it crashes).- Login is very annoying. You need an EA account. Not sure what for, since there's absolutely no online content (was removed from the game after release).- Controls in the 5 stages have nothing in common, except that they all work with mouse and an optional keyboard. It seems the 5 mini games have been designed by completely different teams.This game is not made for adults or adolescents, it's made for kids - and for kids there's no educational value, unlike Civilization, which I played at 10. If you expect a game even remotely similar to Civ, Homeworld, MoO2, or C&C, this game is nothing like any of them. I cannot recommend this game even on a sale, unless you buy it for the creature editor. There are plenty of free to play games that are better, and hundreds of 2$ strategy titles on GoG that are a couple leagues above Spore.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												I've gotten about halfway through the game as of the time I'm writing this, and I think the game does have some value to it, but I'm gonna have to give this one a "not recommend" but with a bit of a clause...See, what Spore tries to do is combine several different genres of games into one. Sounds like a great idea right? But what happens if you dislike one of those genres? Well this is what my experience with Spore has been. The first two "stages" of the game were a lot of fun. It was great creating a species, watching it evolve, and murdering or befriending (mostly murdering) other critters. Unfortunately this fun all came to a screeching halt for me on stage 3, when suddenly all that progress I made, all those parts I collected, and all those parts' abilities were suddenly and completely thrown out the window, and I was dropped in the middle of an RTS.Personally, I despise most RTS games. That's just me. Many people love them, and I don't knock them for loving them, but I hate the vast majority of the ones I've tried. I think Warcraft 2 was probably the one exception. Anyway, digressing a bit. The fun of the game just came to a screeching halt at that point for me, and the game became too annoying to continue.So if there's a specific genre of game you really can't stand, know that this one takes the form of many different ones. Do your homework and make sure no parts of the game are guaranteed to make you cringe before shelling out the cash for this. If this isn't an issue for you, then it's pretty well put together and can be a lot of fun.

												Screw this. I can't log into the EA Spore servers, and all that it says on EA help is that anyone who created an Origin account after 2013 can't log into the server and they are working on the issue. I would definitely ask for my money back if I thought that I could get it because half of the features of this game are playing online with other people. That is why the game askes you to log in online as soon as it launches. Steam or EA should put a large banner or something warning players about this issue with the EA servers. Other users have posted this issue on the EA forums with no response from EA.  This game was not worth the 20 dollars, and is practically only 50% of the game that the developers truly intended to release without online access. I have heard of other people having issue with EA, but I have not had any problems with them until now. I will definitely be cautious in the future if I ever purchase something that they release.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												To anyone over the age of 13, I would NOT recommend this game. I palyed this game when I was around 11 upon its release, and enjoyed it immensely. Evolution intrigued me, as did aliens. Moreover, the community was vibrant, and offered a whole host of unique, interesting other creations. That community is now dead. the majority of accounts and their creations have gone offline, in particular the better creators.Nonetheless, rather than bemoan how much of a blow this game took from EA rushing it out of development, I will say this: the game, even with its many shallow mechanics, will entertain a younger player for a good while. I could see just about anyone getting a solid 50+ hours, maybe over a hundred if they are particularly into the idea of creating creatures. TL;DR: This would be a good purchase for a <13 year old, cannot recommend it to anyone over that age.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												thus begins my outstanding reveiw on spore-------------------------------------------CELL STAGE-----------------------------------------------------------------------the cell stage is based on the feed and grow mechanic. you eat, grow, upgrade and the cycle continues. to be honest i think that this stage couldve been a bit longer or exiting as after the first few minutes the stage becomes repetitive and boring, but not so bad that its unplayable. the ai is decent, not the best in the game but its supposed to be that way.------------------------------------CREATURE STAGE-----------------------------------------------------------------------easily my favorite stage in the game, the creature stage adds a lot of new mechanics and takes you to the surface of your world (eg: lv-420 which is mine). you can befriend or extinct whole species and modify your creature, new and improved with legs and arms. further on in the stage, you can create a team or clan to help you with your tasks. there are a lot of features to unlock for your creature like wings... my favorite. the ai has improved from the last level again, following evolution.-------------------------------TRIBAL STAGE-------------------------------------------------------------------------------from here, this is where my intrest in the game plummits. the tribal stage is similar to age of empires but you can befriend or terminate tribes. when you do this you will get a totem to add to your pole. theres not really much to say now. the ai is about the same as last stage.-------------------------------------CIVILIZATION STAGE--------------------------------------------------------------well isnt it surprising that this stage is like the civ games. you create a city, you send out boats, cars and airships to get resources and to claim or destroy other cities. i cant tell how good the ai is.--------------------------------SPACE STAGE-----------------------------------------------------------------------------♥♥♥♥ this stupid ♥♥♥♥ing stage its so damn ♥♥♥♥ing annoying. the space stage is easily the most fustrating and stupid thing in the game. i can understand the tribal stage and the civ one is a bit ott by THIS... SPACE!! THIS ISNT SPORE WORS (the spelling of wars is intentional) if the're going to put this effort into the game they might aswell just make the game the cell and creature stage because there so much better than the garbage that insues. id play the sims or simcity if i want a civilation simulatior.------------------------------------CREATURE CREATOR------------------------------------------------------------------while this isnt really a stage i thought i would talk about this. this is a great time killer which gives you all the unlockables to create what ever you wish. people who buy the expansion packs can make extrodinary creature with this tool, and people call it that, a tool, one of the best tools in games.------------------------------------------CONCLUSION----------------------------------------------------------------------overall i think that spore was overhyped in its production which led to people discarding the game, me personally didnt follow the game in production and i was still disaapointed with the trio of the final stages. if your going to buy this game do your self a favour and dont play the final 3 missions. play the first 2 only, unless your curious, spore get 3.5 stars out of 5

												Interesting in its own right, spore is a rpg-ish action game based around the growth of a cingle celled organism to an advanced species. While the gameplay is fun if not somewhat repettative, it feels as if the developer of this game had bigger ideas for the game play at the later stages of the spore but instead opted to finish early and collect as much money as possible based on the early gameplay. I like the first 1/4 of the game. The latter falls short. I would pay 2.50 USD for this game only for the early gameplay.. The later gameplay is a waste of time. 3/10

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												To anyone over the age of 13, I would NOT recommend this game. I palyed this game when I was around 11 upon its release, and enjoyed it immensely. Evolution intrigued me, as did aliens. Moreover, the community was vibrant, and offered a whole host of unique, interesting other creations. That community is now dead. the majority of accounts and their creations have gone offline, in particular the better creators.Nonetheless, rather than bemoan how much of a blow this game took from EA rushing it out of development, I will say this: the game, even with its many shallow mechanics, will entertain a younger player for a good while. I could see just about anyone getting a solid 50+ hours, maybe over a hundred if they are particularly into the idea of creating creatures. TL;DR: This would be a good purchase for a <13 year old, cannot recommend it to anyone over that age.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Not much to say about this one to be honest..It's kind of fun and cute to start with, and it makes a lot of promises in terms of making choices that matter - However, once the intro sequence is over and you enter the actual game, everything kind of falls flat and the entire experience gets rather stale. In an extremely repetitive fashion you go from place to place and either fight or make peace, all while finding various upgrades, changing your species and evolving, but a tthe end of the day it's just like adding pieces onto a static clay figure: It never really seems to matter much. Other than finding weird-looking things every now and again there's not much to do, or any real motivation to keep playing the game at all.I can't really recommend it because it feels more like a waste of time than a game. I don't feel immersed while playing it, and I don't feel connected to my 'character' or anything like that. It sort of feels a bit like one of those early 2000 online flash games, just flashier (pun intended) and trying to cover for it's complete lack of soul and substance behind a wall of 'It's all your choice maaan!'.

Posted: July 5, 2014
												Very buggy, Very hard sometimes even on normal. But yet so very fun and replayable. Once you get the galactic adventures DLC the game never ends even if you completed the Space Age you can do quickplay and do random missions in quickplay mode with a captain you can create instantly! My favorite stages are Cell (Basically the minigame starting stage), Creature (After this stage you can't edit your creature anymore), and Space (Random missions made my actual people that are not devs and also trying to take over the whole galaxy is very fun.) Though this game is limited by one galaxy and it starts getting repetitive at times. The tribal stage is basically spores version of an RTS early on. Civilization stage is the same as tribal but longer, still fun by a bit but also they could have done more. Well now my I am done. Choose if you want to or not buy the game. I am not yo mum.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												This game shows promise, but it ultimately fails by way of trying to be a jack of all trades. Each stage of life features a different style of gameplay, and frankly, it's only entertaining during the first few phases when you can evolve your species' DNA. It is at this point which Spore offers something fun and unique.But after enough evolution, your species' body style becomes fixed and then the game turns into a RTS-type game, and then a Civ-like builder, progressing finally into an Endless Space-style universe explorer (and yes, I'm aware that ES was published after Spore... I'm just making a comparison). At this point the game becomes a tedious mess of empire management and stops being innovative and interesting.If Spore was able to increase game complexity while maintaining a focus on evolution, it would be much more interesting as well as entertaining. As it is, it feels like three (or more, depending on how you count) games crammed into a single package.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												Ah, Spore. I've played this when it first came out with its crippling DRM, and limited installs. This current version on steam works a lot better and is a lot easier to just jump right into when you want a game. And that's a big deal. Being able to just fire it up and start making creatures adds so much to the overall experience, while being stuck in DRM hell really puts you off before you've begun. The basic idea was always flawed. As has been said, by trying to go from a bacteria to taking over the galaxy, you just can't cover everything. You end up with 5 minigames rather than one full one. That said, there's something enduring and fun about this that makes it worth a purchase. It's still entertaining to swim your bacteria around, or devour your enemies. I've long since made it to the center of the galaxy (as close as the game has to an end goal) and I still want to come back to this game. If only they'd been more willing to relinquish control from the start and open this game up to modders, they could have added the content this game sorely needed, like fleshing out each section. Still fun, but oh, it could have been so much more. It could have been great.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												Ah, Spore. I've played this when it first came out with its crippling DRM, and limited installs. This current version on steam works a lot better and is a lot easier to just jump right into when you want a game. And that's a big deal. Being able to just fire it up and start making creatures adds so much to the overall experience, while being stuck in DRM hell really puts you off before you've begun. The basic idea was always flawed. As has been said, by trying to go from a bacteria to taking over the galaxy, you just can't cover everything. You end up with 5 minigames rather than one full one. That said, there's something enduring and fun about this that makes it worth a purchase. It's still entertaining to swim your bacteria around, or devour your enemies. I've long since made it to the center of the galaxy (as close as the game has to an end goal) and I still want to come back to this game. If only they'd been more willing to relinquish control from the start and open this game up to modders, they could have added the content this game sorely needed, like fleshing out each section. Still fun, but oh, it could have been so much more. It could have been great.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												I have heard about this game when it released and knew that the Maxis studio had done quite the job getting pretty good reviews.This studio has always been sort of a Disney-like software developer for me thinking of the style they use in the various SIM-games. Somehow that withheld me from playing it at the time, i guess i was more into the more advanced and mature kind of gaming at the time.Now that the game is really cheap i decided to give it a go, remembering the hype back in the days.I must say that i am really impressed and i think i still have lots to see and discover.The great thing is that you can see this game was a real innovator combining different kinds of gaming genres almost seamless into eachother. ofcourse this brings in the danger of favoriting certain parts of the game to some, but still.I found my self playing this game well into the morning from the first go proving the game engages players from the start...which is impressive for a game that may well be called an oldy anno 2015.Except for the parts where i found my progress to go too fast and me wanting to stay in the current gamephase instead of progressing ( which can be postponed so i guess it's not that big a deal :) ) i find this game is near perfection and a very good choice when you are looking for a varied and i must say..relaxing game.originality, content, replayability, humour, freedom of choice and a gamepath that certainly can't be called too short and even achievements ( which must have been one of the first games having those i guess )...this game has all these things.Be careful when you try this one....you might find yourself regretting not playing this game earlier like me ;)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Spore is an interesting concept that suffers from lack of consistency throughout its gameplay and lack of replayability.The beginning of the game shows you all of the greatness of spore - creating your race, consuming other beings, and swimming around in a cesspool of creative and dangerous creatures. As soon as you evolve to the point of being able to go on land and interact with multicellular beings, the game's attraction begins to diminish. Now you're fighting with other races, using a mixture of "evolved" traits that can be changed at any time and generic attacks, and utilizing an overly simplistic mechanic to communicate and befriend them. Next  thing you know, you evolve far enough that you can create weapons and buildings and you're playing any other generic RTS. All the cool racial choices you've made thus far in order to survive become completely cosmetic and useless. The game itself doesn't take very long to progress from cell to this world dominator phase.I cannot recommend purchasing this game at full price, or even while it's on sale. If you've realling been pining for it, get it while it's on sale. But even so, there are many games that are more deserving of your time.
